description:
And WHAT A MID WEEK DINNER ....I have not been this happy after eating a RISOTTO ever...Light , airy and very very smooth ...
Risotto with corn and Truffle butter ...
Pan roared Salmon  with deconstructed Ratatouille and Tomato broth ...
I am Sad that I didn't click any pics, because I couldn't stop eating....
BUT I did click the picture or The DESSERT...Mini donughts with Lavender sugar and Lemon custard ...
MUST TRY FOR LUNCH  AND DINNER ...
A place worth the money for everything ....
author: Abhilasha S.

description:
Good coffee.   Inconsistent service and weird menu items.   I don't eat cheese so pretty much my option is oatmeal that tastes way way too sweet or a muffin. Once I asked for eggs and toast and told I can't have toast.   The other breakfasts come with toast. 

Hash browns? No,  tater tots. 

Overpriced and extremely uncomfortable furniture. Location and nice building give the third star.
author: Larry W.

description:
Hash= Hard little diced pieces of corned beef the texture of rehydrated jerky sautéed with peas and chunked potatoes. Where's the luxurious crispness ? 

Poached eggs with polenta= two soft poached eggs surrounded by a wet bed of tomatoey liquid, par-cooked sliced pearl onions, and wet cubes of bacon. Maybe a spoonful of polenta in total hidden somewhere in the dish. Crispy fried broccoli which makes no sense on the plate but would have been lovely as it's own dish wish some aioli and lemon. 

Bizarre, what are they thinking in the kitchen back there? The textures were all over the place and not at all appetizing. The only thing on point was the toast... at least they got that right. I gave points for the flavor of some of the individual components (broccoli, and the potatoes were seasoned correctly).

Very disappointing as I can tell there is skill and good ideas in someone back there, just very poor execution. :(
author: Isabella E.

description:
1. Nice, clean, upscale atmosphere. Good for formal occasions and big groups.

2. Had their fix menu for brunch. It is a multi-course family style meal, $25 per person. It is NOT a buffet. 

3. The food was decent overall. Everything was a blur given there were so many dishes. I was satisfied at the end though. 

4. The staff was friendly and attentive.
author: Eileen H.

description: We went here for drinks after a show at Bill Graham. It's on a block that doesn't have much around it, but don't let that fool you. Once you walk in, you're in good hands. You can do a drink downstairs at the bar, have a bite there, or do a more extended dinner upstairs. The bar tenders know their stuff, and the staff is super friendly. We're coming back for sure.
author: Karl R.

description:
Corridor is a trendy and upscale environment. The ambience Corridor emits almost pairs well with the food and service.

I do knock a bit off of service. Not for the fact the the servers are bad, it just seems like the restaurant is stretched very thin. It took about 15 minutes before I was handed a menu, even more to place an order. Workers are scrambling about and it unfortunately created an experience leaving more to be desired.

To begin my meal, I started off with the popular monkey bread. These are mostly ready-to-bake and it reflects on the texture. A stale and oily bread is what you mostly get. There is some good flavor here, unfortunately the raison d'etre simply falls short of average.

The meatballs were another unsatisfying plate. When one orders meatballs, especially if it's the item's namesake, one expects a hearty amount of protein. The plating literally hides the meatballs. There's cheese slices, basil, and croutons (why??). Then again this might be because they are hiding the meatballs sad and frozen flavor.

My main course was actually great. I got the Green Garlic Pesto Campanelle. The pesto flavor really was the star and the details of flavor elevated the plate to a surprising level, given the past plates performance.

I ended my meal with an okay dessert, 'Nilla Pudding Tart. I don't know what I was tasting. There's just a big scoop of mush and taking one bite you don't really taste much from it. You'll either get small hints of chocolate or a strong force of peanut butter. The dish just seemed lost and confused.
author: Vinh T.

description:
Dinner after the SHN matinee..  Walked in and were immediately greeted.   They checked us in and then gave us a token of some sort with instructions to head up stairs and give it to our server to be seated.  

Upstairs we go!  Not a bad climb...  

Once seated, water and menus were brought.  Drinks ordered and we discussed appetizers with our server.  They suggested the monkey bread and calamari..  Okay we'll give it a try..   

Our drinks arrived following quickly by the bread.    While it was tasty, it was not what I'd call monkey bread..  The chive overpowered the cheese, or it needed more cheese in my opinion..   The calamari was perfect !   The Harissa aioli and olive tapenade on it was amazing.   Everyone at the table enjoyed it.  For mains we enjoyed Garganelli bolognese, asparagus risotto, and Da Burga!    Everything was tasty and not salty..  We were full after but the 4 of us shared the chocolate budino.   Mmmmmm

The staff was engaging and attentive..  Waters glasses were kept full..  Silverware replaced as needed. 

Great time and good food..
author: Susanne R.

description: The restaurant and food looks amazing but we came here stuffed so can only rate the bar experience. Bartenders are creative, knowledgeable, and friendly with the perfect level of oversight (there when you want something, out of sight when you're deep in conversation). Overall, a great experience completely to par with what's expected from the Stones Throw / Trestle clan...
author: K B.

description:
Probably the most confusing menu and restaurant  I have ever experienced. 
My friend and I got welcomed by a very nice gentleman upon arrival who handed us a "chip". I thought it was for coat check as he advised us to walk upstairs to the second floor. Was coat check on the second floor?! Nope. That's where the restaurant was. 
We literally had no clue what was going on. 
Turns out the sit down nice dinners are happening  upstairs and the quick bistro / cafe  style eats are happening downstairs. 

The menu: creative. But couldn't tell what this restaurant's theme was and what kind of culinary message and experience I was going to have.  

The reason this place got a 3 was because the service was a 5+++. Our server went above and beyond with service. 

The food - while everyone's flavor buds are going to create a subjective opinion - this was not a winner. Small portions. Light flavors. 
Felt like a tourist spot where the food didn't matter and the ooh- aahs are from coming from the great service and the unique venue.
author: Zita M.

description:
Came here for dinner after the symphony.  They weren't super busy but someone must have called in sick because the 1 waiter working that shift was hustling!  The ambiance is nice - love the big windows and spaciousness of it though I think I'd appreciate it more as a cafe / lunch spot then dinner.  

It was a short menu, but while we were waiting for the table we saw the beautiful puff on the pot pie and were sold.  Unfortunately the pot pie itself when it finally arrived was disappointing.  It didn't have enough sauce (like it was left in the oven too long or that it was missing chicken ...) and was rather bland.  The puff pastry on top was golden delicious, but the pie was bleh.  Hubby got a burger which he ate and didn't complain about.
author: Kathleen W.

description:
A girlfriend and I we're going to the ballet. Since Corridor was close by, I made a dinner reservation about a month and a half prior through OpenTable for Wednesday, March 21st at 5:45pm. We were seated upstairs at a table in the corner.

They have a $5 happy hour, Monday through Friday, 3pm - 6pm. It applies to draft beer, wines by the glass, and cocktails. And you can still take advantage if you are sitting at a table. So go ahead and make a reservation if you want to guarantee yourself a seat. Since my gf was running late, I got myself a glass of Sparkling: m bonnamy brut, loire valley, france nv (regularly $10), and her a glass of Cabernet Sauvignon: vinum 'the insider', paso robles, ca 2014 (regularly $12). During dinner I switched to the cab as I'm more of a red wine girl. I believe my gf had one more while I had two more glasses. Too bad HH didn't go until 7pm, as it would have been great if they were still $5 each.

*Little Gem Lettuces: crispy bacon, avocado, dijon vinaigrette, herb crisp ($13)
*Asparagus Risotto: black truffle butter, button mushrooms, parmesan cream ($15)
*Herb-Crusted Pork Porterhouse: creamy farro, glazed fall root vegetables, mustard jus ($24)

My gf and I shared everything, so I thought this was a good sampling of things. I adored the risotto. So creamy. And that truffle aroma and flavor. So good! The salad was tasty as well, but I found the vinaigrette a little one note. I kind of wished they offered us fresh ground pepper for contrast. Instead of the pork porterhouse, we actually got the loin and rib. I believe the preparation was still the same though. Same price as well. The pork was cooked nicely. Flavorful and tender. The rib was a little drier though as the meat was tough.

Fun place for HH and dinner before going to a show. I've been wanting to check this place out for some time. Glad I finally had an excuse. Great HH drink specials!
author: Elena N.

description: Definitely my go-to place for happy hour drinks and food with good company. $5 draft beers and glass wines with delicious food to munch on. Atmosphere is basically chill, weekend afternoon vibes with big windows looking out the street. It can get pretty loud when it's crowded though. Variety of draft beers and wines. Monkey bread is their signature dish. Fried calamari is delicious too. All the dishes I've tried so far have not disappointed me yet. If you are here for just drinks, order simple dishes like monkey bread or fried calamari! Waiters are quick with orders and decent $$. Good for catch up over some drinks. I'd always grab drinks and food here to catch up with a friend working nearby. Wide interior space with communal tables on the first floor with high ceiling, clean restrooms, and a nice bar.
author: Adel A.

description: Vegetable pot pie was delicious and our service was fantastic! Sitting upstairs for dinner was nice on a warmer day in SF. They also gave us a great tomato salad on the house.
author: Taylor L.

description:
Wow what a great find in the city! We stumbled across this cozy little restaurant right beside the Nourse Theatre and decided to give it a shot. 

Luckily we caught the tail-end of happy hour and ordered a Rosé and Sparkling for $5 each and then shared the Monkey Bread, Roasted Root Vegetable Salad, and Carbonara. The Monkey Bread was light yet savory, the vegetables were a refreshing addition to the rich and heavy pasta, but all were delicious in their own right.

To make things even better, the service in there was superb! The waiters were friendly and attentive to our needs and were prompt with bringing in the food. We even forgot our leftovers by accident and had to double back for it, only to find that they had saved them for us beside the counter. Would not hesitate to bring my friends here for another round!
author: Allison T.

description:
3.75/5- Rounding up for the fantastic service
Came here with some friends on a Saturday night for a quick meal before a show. This place has a pleasant open atmosphere and absolutely fantastic service. Prices aren't too bad either.

We ordered the following:
1) Monkey Bread: The bread itself was average but it was soft and fun to eat. The chive oil was a nice touch as well. The basil aioli could've been a bit stronger but overall a good sharing appetizer (3.5/5)

2) Crispy Duck Confit: I've had a lot of misses when it comes to duck confit but this was solid all around. The duck has a smooth and tender but the exterior had a nice crisp. The highlight was definitely the forbidden rice which was mixed with a light peking sauce and more duck. However I believe they also slightly fried it which gave it a wonderful texture. It was also a decent size. (4.5/5)

3) Garganelli Bolognese w/ burrata & calabrian chili: My main entree for the night  and apparently one of their specialties. I couldn't decide between this and the burger and the waiter said if its your first time this is one of their main dishes though he'd personally go for the burger next time. First of all the dish looks small but is deceivingly filling. The meat tasted almost like a sausage and I wish there was more of it cause it was full of flavor. The burrata was also a great subtle touch of flavor. I also appreciated they used a ton of basil. Besides these highlights the dish was average. I do agree it's something that's nice to try once but not quite amazing either (3.5/5)

Overall, Corridor was a filling tasty meal and a perfect pre-show dinner stop. I would definitely consider revisiting.
author: Vivian C.

description:
New place for us, apparently it's been open about 18 months now. By day it's more casual counter-service restaurant, at night it has table service including the upstairs area. The menu looked good and reasonably priced so we thought we'd give it a try pre-theater. Boy am I glad we did! So many good choices and options...I'm on the fence between 4 and 5 stars...I'd say 4.5 if I could.

As for the food...onion soup was great...croutons and nice cheese with onion soup with real depth. Last 3 onions soups i've ordered (not here) have really disappointed me...this one didn't and lived up to what it should. Monkey bread is off the hook. It's basically like a brioche...butter filled, light and airy like a cloud with some cheddar cheese and some garlic aioli to spread on yourself. The spicy meatballs were ok...the sauce was nice with a little kick, but the meatballs themselves were not as tender and not hot all the way through which was disappointing. We also had the fried calamari, which was also so-so...needed more seasoning.

For mains we got were all solidly prepared. The tagliattelle carbonara was full of little surprises like croutons, fresh pasta and little pancetta bits. The risotto with a wonderful truffle kiss.

Also, our service that night with Caley was fantastic. Super thoughtful, attentive and not intrusive and very personable. We really enjoyed our meal and it's well priced given other options of similar or lesser quality in the area. Will definitely be back again!
author: David L.

description:
Im usually a researcher but was working next door and randomly swung in here. So glad I did! Its fine dining for applebees prices with a diverse menu. Being super hungry I ordered both the cheesy pull apart monkey bread app and the garganelli bolognese pasta. Its a fancy upscale yet casual enviorment with excellent service.

The monkey pull apart bread was light airy and cheesy and the real MVP was the creamy chive dipping sauce tho it was also good dipped in the pasta sauce. While not an italian restaurant I was in a pasta mood and it was among the best iv had. Its in an orange sauce and topped with meat, fresh basil, and some creamy cheesy goodness. It was filling on its own and came with a quality slice of bread. Really glad I tried this place.
author: Sean G.

description:
Had a lovely date night with my husband this Saturday night at Corridor. OpenTable made last-minute reservations easy and we didn't wait at all upon arriving 15 minutes early. I'd like to preface this by saying both hubs and I are doing intermittent fasting, so this was our first meal after 16 hours of not eating and boy, was it worth it. Started off with a couple of beers and the pull-apart monkey bread (so good!). We also had the spicy meatballs which had an amazing kick and that sauce was divine.

For entrees, we had the steak with potatoes and I had the salmon with beat salad. The salmon came out pretty raw so I could not finish it, but my husband loved his steak and potatoes. They were kind enough to not charge us for my dish, which I found surprisingly thoughtful and also rare, as I did not ask for this. We took the banana creme pie to go (delish as well), and as we were leaving we saw someone going to town on a cheeseburger that looked heavenly. Total food envy, people, but I will be back for that... ::: laughs evilly :::
author: Joanna R.

description:
NOOOOOOOOOO ...........................

No more Monkey Bread.. (tear).

Was initially very upset and disappointed that they had run out of Monkey Bread cause I've read such great things about it but after having a fine dining experience here.... I guess this just gives me more of a reason to return! hehe

To share amongst our party of 4:

SWEET CORN SOUP ($10): Poached Shrimp, Lime, Thai Basil, Coconut, Chili. Wow, did this app give us a scare. When the waiter brought the soup over, it was just a bowl of toppings fit for just one person, then he poured the soup over it and we were like Ohhhh... okay....The soup was rich, creamy, sweet, and very tasty (almost like thai curry). Incorporated with some potatoes and corn gave a nice pop. Sharable amongst two. 

MUSSELS & CLAMS ($15): Spicy Fregola, Capers, Toasted Bread. this app was alright. Taste was just okay but had a spicy kick to it. mussels and clams were just super duper tiny. probably won't order again..

GARGANELLI BOLOGNESE ($16): Burrata, Basil, Calabrian Chili. My friend got this and it was absolutely yummy. The pasta was cooked al dente, cheesy, rich, and full of flavors. Definitely must try!

PAN-ROASTED SALMON ($22) Clams, Bacon Lardon, Confit Potato, Chowder style broth. The salmon was cooked medium rare: crispy on the outside but super soft on the inside. Taste was simple with enough flavors from the chowder broth. 

HALF ROAST CHICKEN ($19): Made with Brocollini Panzanella and Calabrian Chili Vinaigrette. The brocollini was simply delicious! The chicken was juicy, most, and flavorful. Woo hoo. so far so good!

DUCK CONFIT ($23): Duck... omg. the duck was really good. With the forbidden black rice was a nice finishing touch. Only downside was the rhubarb... SUPER sour..

DRINKS:
Consists mostly of wine and beer. They didn't have a full bar. Had only 4 low proof mixed drinks on the menu so bleh..... I opted for the sauvignon blanc ($9) which was crisp and refreshing (paired nicely with my salmon). The others liked their drinks as well. Also tried my friend's Peanut Butter Stout for the first time and it was surprisingly not bad! 

A BONUS was that they accepted my last minute call-in reservation for my party of 4 literally 40 minutes prior to arriving at 8:30pm. The ambiance and decor was very hip and casual with wide open windows and an open view to their kitchen! There's two floors: upstairs for reservations and downstairs for first come first serve. Right when we entered, the host gave us a key and we took it upstairs and gave it to the waiter and he brought us to our table! So cute... omg. like a corridor key!! Service was attentive. Had some good recommendations by Sarah and she accommodated my shrimp allergy with the Sweet corn soup. 

Definitely gonna return to try their Monkey Bread and French Onion Soup. 

For 4 people: 2 apps, 4 entrees, 4 drinks was ~$193 pre-tip.
author: Anissa D.

description:
4.5 stars. I've definitely been missing out on some great restaurants because Nina Y. and I don't dine out as much as we used to. For our first dinner together in awhile, I chose Corridor Restaurant because it was close to Civic Center station on both of our ends. I got here early, so I sat at one of the high tables and waited. I noticed that this is a popular coffee shop during the day, then turns into a classy dinner setting in the evening. With high ceilings, two stories, and glass walls, this makes quite the charming and classy spot!

For dinner, we couldn't resist starting with the Monkey Bread because Nina makes a great chocolatey one, while this one is savory. Simply put, it's pull-apart bread with cheddar cheese and chive oil. So good! For our main course, Nina got the Garganelli Bolognese, and I got the Sweet Corn Risotto. Both were amazing dishes! The flavors and textures were on point. I would high recommend the Risotto, which has truffle butter, maitake mushrooms, and parmesan.

Service is also warm and welcoming here. The ambiance overall was a highlight of our experience, and if you're looking for casual spot to have a meal that's on the nicer sider, consider coming to Corridor Restaurant! Get here or make a reservation while the sun is setting, because it's absolutely gorgeous.
author: Stefanie C.

description:
Stopped in because I couldn't wait another step without sustenance! What a treat to rest route turned out to be! The little gem salad is fantastic: Crispy bacon, fresh avocado, nice dressing: not too much just perfect. The calamari had a little spicy tang to it; best thing about it was not chewy!
I sat at a communal table and was almost envious that I did not order the burger! The cheddar cheese was melted gloriously over the burger, yet the bun was crispy and not soggy!
Fun vibes, great for a quick bite!
author: Mary W.

description: Conceptually great but I'm going to echo others comments here especially when it comes to inconsistent/"weird" service. Staff seem super easily stressed out and not everyone seem to be aware of certain things like the special program (delivery, discount... cashier didn't know so had to escalate to the manager) for 150/100VN. Again, inconsistent (with a bit of nonchalance and awkwardness) service without guiding principles really is the main issue here.
author: Han L.

description:
3.5 stars, rounded down to a 3  

Got a reservation for 7 on a Sunday night like 2 hours before! Upon getting to the restaurant it became clear that a reservation was not necessary because there was basically nobody there.

The good: 
* My bolognese w/ burrata was delicious and at $16, just the right price. 
* My friends' duck w/ forbidden rice was plated prettily, tasted fine 

The bad: 
* Beef tartare had a lot of random other things in it (root veggies, beets and the like), which made it seem less worth the price.  
* The monkey bread was much smaller than it looks in the Yelp pics, tasted very mediocre - not worth getting to share.  
* Got a Pimm's - I know Pimm's are quite sweet to begin with, so I won't gripe about that, but for a drink priced at $8 it probably should've been stronger on the alc. 

The ugly: 
* My friend's salmon dish was supposed to come with clams (according to the menu). When the dish came, my friend didn't see any clams, and the waiter told her that her that it was because the clam was prepared out of the shell and was hidden under the vegetables. She finished the entire dish, and still no clams were to be found...so, did the waiter just make random crap up and actually had no idea what was in the dish?? 

This place has potential - I'll be back for the bolognese, but maybe not much else...
author: Anna C.

description:
I was pleasantly surprised to learn Corridor has the same owners as Stone's Throw, which I've gone to for brunch and liked. However, I wasn't wowed by anything here and found all the dishes standard with no wow-factor. 
  
RESERVATIONS: Made online a week in advance for six people at 1:30pm on a Saturday. We were the only table upstairs - props to our server who basically stayed on to serve us!

SHAREABLES
* Monkey Bread ($7) - 3.5 stars
Nice lightly toasted texture, but this had much less cheese than I expected based on the videos everyone has posted on Yelp of the bread being pulled apart.

BREAKFAST
* Butter Fried Pancake (w/ choc, hazelnut, banana stuffing $13) - 3 stars
Sounds great in theory, is this giant huge pancake, but was very dry (and the banana and hazelnut were not stuffed but were toppings).

* Breakfast sandwich ($12) - 3.5 stars
Good but standard. Tater tots have a thick crisp.

LUNCH
* Shrimp Roll ($16) - 3 stars
Decent, the shrimp wasn't too fresh, bread slightly stale. Didn't love the celery.

DESSERT
* Nilla Tart ($8) - 3.5 stars
Classic flavors. Not too much wow-factor. The crust was dry and stale.
author: Ziyan C.

description:
4.5 stars. Excellent place if you want to grab quick meal. Not formal. Can sit downstairs (more roomy with high ceiling but louder) or in the mezzanine (not as bright but quieter during happy hour evening time. 

Service is fantastic here. I came in here between rehearsal and concert with 4 people and they were able to serve us 4 different dishes and get us out in 30 minutes, which was phenomenal given the quality of the food.  Love he hostess. 

MUST GET:
The vegetable pot pie is great - ultimate comfort food. 

heirloom tomato salad with burrata - fantastic Cherokee heirloom tomatoes with soft burrata and parsley. 

Sweet Corn risotto with maitake mushroom and truffle butter - delicious and decadent but not too creamy and heavy. Beautiful flavors and just the right consistency. Gorgeous dish. 

SOLID:

The French onion soup is pretty good - good guyere cheese but didn't care for the bread pieces. 

Garganelli bolognese - like the pasta here. The tomato meat sauce was solid but didn't stand out like the other dishes - the tomatoes can be more concentrated in flavor and the sauce a bit more chunky. Burrata was an interesting touch here. 

AVOID:
I didn't like the 5 pea salad - some type of herb that is amuse like ruined the flavor. 

Spicy Meatballs - mediocre. I would skip. 

----

The seats are not that comfortable- not for hanging out for hours. 

The Bomenay sparking rose was delicious!
author: Rebecca C.

description:
Corridor is a great place for happy hour and dinner. I met a couple of my friends there and the place was amazing. We started off with the monkey bread, which I was sadden to discover there was no monkey inside (jk).

I had the prime NY striploin, which was amazingggg.  Someone ordered the scallops which was also very good and cooked just right.   And there was a bunch of other foods but i don't remember cause i drank a little too much :O  The drinks were just like me - exuberant and tasty :)

For dessert we had the chocolate budino. I think budino is Italian for diabetes cause i ate like most of it myself.  Sweet, diabetes.  Oh yeah the service was impeccable.
author: Huy D.

description:
Recently came here to try a relatively new menu item - the oh-so-trendy Fried Chicken Sandwich.

One word:   Yum.

It was worthy.  Especially considering how many places "around here" offer great chicken sandwiches (yes Rusty's Southern and The Bird, that includes you).
author: Lewis C.

description:
Great location before the symphony, opera or jazz concert.  

To start we shared the mussels and clams.  Spicy with a wonderful broth and tiny little pasta like bits. I would definitely order again.

We had the Bolognese pasta and the duck confit as main dishes.  Both were very good, although the confit was a little dry.  Nice blend of vegetables and black rice.

One of the really wonderful things they do is document allergies on the order so the cooks know even if the server is not sure of ingredients.

We did not have time for dessert--and I am allergic to all of them.

The menu is somewhat limited but a nice looking beer/wine selection.
author: Joanna S.

description:
I have been here once for happy hour, once for a sort-of-event, and once before an event in the area. It's your best bet for a convenient spot for drinks before any events at the War Memorial, Davies Symphony Hall, or Bill Graham, if you don't walk all the way to Hayes Valley. I wish their happy hour was longer than 6 pm, but the $5 drinks and food specials are worth the hustle over after work. 

For the event, they were extremely courteous about guiding everyone over to our reserved tables and making sure everyone had drinks or silverware, although it was chaotic to try to keep track. We just ordered multiple rounds of the appetizers, which were all good. However, unless they split them into smaller sizes to pass around for us, it's pricey for the amount that you get of appetizers.

They are mostly a wine bar, with about a dozen beers and some low-proof drinks if you prefer something else. I do wish they had at least two or three stronger cocktails, but maybe it's something to do with alcohol permits. Our server was helpful in suggesting some sour beers or reds for me. She also gets bonus points for going around asking all the men on staff or at neighboring tables if they could tie a bowtie for me before I went to a wedding!
author: Cat N.

description: I like the atmosphere. The internal is very clean and just nice. I got the croissant egg sandwich. The egg was disgusting. Over cooked fake egg with a slice of cheese in the middle, rolled up. The croissant and scallion creme fraiche were okay. Maybe ask how the egg is prepared next time.
author: Melissa D.

description: Absolutely the slowest service and it wasn't even busy. It was often 30 minutes between courses and none of the wait staff checked in. The food was fine but not worth the cost or the wait.
author: Nemo N.

description:
This place was good, but not one of my favorites.

A couple of positives:

1. The staff is incredibly nice and very present throughout the whole meal. We never needed to hunt them down for anything.
2. The food was good for the most part! I enjoyed the calamari and most of the vegetable pot pie (see negatives below).
3. The ambiance is incredible - it's good for a date night. I also liked the fact that it was multi-story. The second floor was definitely more intimate than the first, which makes sense as to why people with reservations are seated upstairs.

A few negatives:

1. The bottom parts of the vegetable pot pie tasted like the skillet - it was very odd so I didn't eat the bottom of the pie. The crust and the middle, however, were very tasty.
2. I booked this reservation through Opentable and mentioned that when I walked in. However, they didn't mark that I showed up so I got an email from Opentable asking why I missed my reservation. It was added hassle for no reason if the restaurant had marked that I showed up.
3. The dinner options are minimal - review the menu before deciding to go!

All-in all, it's a good restaurant for a date night, but there are better options out there in my point of view.
author: Remy B.

description:
Popped into this cool spot just outside the Mission for a late lunch with a new friend. Our timing was perfect! The restaurant was quiet and seating was plentiful. 

The setting is trendy, but still cozy. The stools are less than comfy, but tolerable. It's easy to imagine the noise level, when busy, might be kinda loud with so many smooth and glassy surfaces in the room. 

The fella who took our order was pleasant and patiently offered info (and beer tastings!) while we explored the menu.

My half chicken was great, and my choosey friend loved the salmon! Both dishes had lots of flavor and were perfectly cooked.

The yummy-looking monkey bread was hard to resist, but I will plan my calories accordingly before my next visit so I can partake guilt-free!

Minus one star for no calorie counts on the menu.
author: Tony B.

description:
Eating here was like eating at a restaurant in the airport. It felt overly contrived, the food was very expensive and not very good. The Monkey Bread and Calamari were both recommended by the server and tasted like something from Trader Joe's that had been previously frozen. The upstairs is small and you need a weird keychain number to get up there, for no discernible reason. The downstairs is like a place you go for a beer after work and leave as quickly as possible. All concept, no comfort, satisfaction or deliciousness.

The service was amazing though. 5 stars for the workers. They were so attentive and kind. Too bad the food is such crap.
author: Nicole M.

description:
Made a last minute dinner reservation last night at the Corridor. 

We ordered the items below:

Monkey Bread ($6) - Pull-Apart Bread with Cheddar Cheese, Chive Oil, Basil Aioli. It was really good better than the ones from Stones Throw. 

Spicy Meatballs ($10)- Tomato-Braised, Parmesan, Focaccia Croutons, Rosemary. I'm not a fan of meatballs but I liked this dish. It wasn't too spicy and it went well with the monkey bread together. 

Pan-Roasted Salmon ($22) - Clams, Bacon Lardon, Confit Potato, Chowder Style Broth. Salmon was perfect and the chowder style broth added great flavor to this dish. 

Meatloaf Wellington ($23) - Creamed Spinach, Orach Salad, Bordelaise Vinaigrette. I didn't order this but was able to try the dish. It was okay. The meatloaf didn't have much flavor. You have to rely on the other ingredients on the plate to enjoy it. It was just not that enjoyable. Glad I didn't order it.

Chocolate Walnut Brownie Sundae  ($8) - I love desserts so this was good. We shared it cause we were full after our entree.

Environment- The restaurant was really spacious and open. We were seated upstairs by the counter facing the entrance. It was loud at times but was able to talk to my partner without having to yell.

Overall, I would definitely recommend this place. The price was reasonable and not too expensive! 

I'll come here again!
author: Jennifer B.

description:
Happy hour is a solid 4/5. I mean, $5 for normally $8-10 priced cocktails? I'd tap those drinks. The deal applies to the wines, beer, and low liquor mixed drinks on the front of the menu. "But no one brought me the menu!" you say. Check those wooden ledges poking out from the table. Maybe hang your bag on the hooks stuck to the table legs. Other considerations aside, I like the design thought put into this place - you don't even need a patio to enjoy the sunshine with their floor to ceiling windows! 

We arrived early and managed to get a table all to ourselves (4 seats, but you can squish 6), but pretty soon people had filled up the bar seating as well and were milling around. You'll notice you have to raise your voice as well as the evening gets on. Our table initially had a "Reserved" sign, but the perky staff pointed us there so we shrugged and made ourselves comfortable. The actual restaurant area is located upstairs, and I had no reason to venture up there as one of the bathrooms was located conveniently 10 feet behind me. 

One of the mixed drinks had already run out (huh? before 6pm?), but my friend's Pimm's Cup looked gorgeous (and supposedly tasted so too), and my Gone with the Wind drink went down smooth and velvet-like. Solid marks all around for the non-alcoholic (and non-latte) Matcha Green Tea drink also.

The rest of the drink and appetizer menu looked decent, but without happy hour coverage, none of our party wanted to venture into overpriced territory. If I return, it will probably still be to the comfortable land of Happy Hour.
author: Helen S.

description:
I've got mad love for the Hi Neighbor group. 

They've certainly got the Midas touch when it comes to opening restaurants. From the classy Stone's Throw to the incredibly affordable Trestle and the cozy wine bar Fat Angel. Corridor is the latest addition and is planted in mid-Market area where some restaurants like Cadence and Oro didn't have a chance of surviving. But Corridor has longevity and these are the reasons why:

1. It's their ability to combine healthy California cuisine and indulgent comfort food
2. $5 cocktails, beer and wine for happy hour EVERY DAY. (so important during these hard times!) 
3. It's a cafe, a casual hangout spot and an upscale dinner place rolled into one.

It maybe confusing at first when you walk in, as the counter person checks you in and can also take in your orders as well. You can get your drinks at the bar or order food and grab a seat at one of the communal tables. If you made a rezzie, you're given a number to be taken to the mezzanine where a full service experience awaits. The best seats are the counter ones facing the tall glass panels which gives you a view of the bustling street below. 

I've been twice and both times opted for the mezzanine dining. You must order the Monkey Bread. It's a cake like bread served warm, topped with cheddar cheese, chive oil accompanied with basil aioli. Or their healthy version of the deep fried calamari served with leeks and olive tapenade. More heartier items include the roast chicken served with seasonal veggies atop garlic mashed potatoes or the loosely packed medium burger with melted cheddar, secret sauce and pickled slaw. This is comfort food at its finest and even more alluring is the fact that, entrees are all $23 and below! 

I'll constantly have Corridor in my radar when near Civic Center. It's perfect for catch up with gfs before going to a concert at Bill Graham or dining out with parents before they hop on BART back to the burbs. Corridor is a winner.
author: Janice C.

description:
It took me awhile to write this review because I tried suppressing the memory of my experience here. I came here early May for my graduation dinner with a few of my close girlfriends and the horrendous customer service that we experienced, makes all of us not ever want to go back.

We were seated upstairs, and our waiter was Haley (Kaley?). He was the main server, that I could see upstairs. The start of the night was fine, everything was going well until he took our order for our entrees, which we had waited to do after we finished our appetizers. I ordered first and wanted the burger. When asked how I would like it prepared, I answered "medium to medium rare" because of how wide the range is, there is less room for mistakes as well as it gives the chef more of an idea of what I would like. I have asked this request many many times before at different restaurants around the city (Spruce, Michael Mina, Gary Danko etc) and have never had anyone say "No, we can't do that" before. With a puzzled look on my face, I asked "Why?" He explains that the restaurant only offered medium or medium rare, there is no spectrum for the middle. I was already thrown off because not a lot of servers would say "No" in such a brash and condescending tone. I then told him that I didn't have a problem with various restaurants when making this request before, and I was honestly confused as to why they couldn't do it or even say instead "We can try to accommodate that but on the event that we can't which one would you prefer?" Instead I got "Maybe you haven't been to restaurants that know how to cook." Wow. Ok. Then I got pissed. And I knew he could see it in my face and curt responses so he stooped to my level and asked me again if I preferred medium or medium rare in such a condescending tone I wanted to get up and leave.

This as well as a series of other events (this was the huge main one) made me feel crappy the rest of the night. I didn't want to be THAT person and tell the manager since I could tell they were busy and I went back and forth in writing this review. But I felt like the management has the right to know how poorly their staff is being trained and treating their customers because the table next to us was also having problems with him and rolling their eyes whenever he asked them something in his tone. I definitely won't be coming back and will tell my friends who ask about this place the same. It's actually really disappointing because the food was actually good.
author: M T.

description: What a fantastic stop for dinner on the way to the theater!  Had reservations that were going to cut it close to the start time.  We let the waiter know that it was going to be a quick meal.  We gave them the time we needed to be out by and ordered.  Food was amazing, wine suggestions matched perfectly, they had us out before our goal time.  Overall an amazing experience and we will be back to sample more of the menu!
author: Lindsay B.

description:
I had a great experience at Trestle previously, and was excited to see that the same group opened Corridor Restaurant. My friends made reservations here for a large group dinner, which meant we had to order the dishes ahead of time, and everything would be served family style. This was perfect for our group since we all love to share. The prix fixe began at $45/person (before tax + tip), although we did pay a supplemental fee for a few of the dishes. It ended up being a crazy amount of food, and you really get your bang for the buck. 

I loved the appetizers and pasta courses, but the mains and dessert were just ok. However, I'm keeping the review at 5 stars since our server was awesome. We walked into Corridor Cafe, and were a bit confused at first since it was so casual. Corridor Restaurant is actually up the stairs, and provides a more intimate dining experience since the area isn't very big. We tried:

3 Starters:
-Monkey Bread (Pull-Apart Bread w/Cheddar Cheese, Chive Oil, https://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=Ufp6ebCVpNbOwAyY_x9DOg&userid=76vIFZcC7owykCBjMfGVXg): Super buttery and cheesy deliciousness. The additional butter/dipping sauce was also delicious, and it was difficult to stop eating this- a must try!
-Mussels & Clams (Spicy Fregola, Capers, White Wine, Toasted Bread, + $1 Supplement/Person, https://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=qPKkSk-IyPWfI4WG-OJy9w&userid=76vIFZcC7owykCBjMfGVXg): This dish was very flavorful, and the mussels and clams were cooked perfectly. I loved the hummus like spread at the bottom of this dish, which was perfect with the toasted bread- recommended!
-Beef Tartar (Shaved Ducked Liver Mousse, Tokyo Turnips, Truffle Vinaigrette, +$1.50 Supplement/Person, https://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=Nb8bDdHP5ePCg6uQpP3V6A&userid=76vIFZcC7owykCBjMfGVXg): Yum- the beef tartar was really fresh, and the flavors in this dish worked well together. Recommended!

Pasta Course
-Yellow Corn Risotto (Maitake Mushrooms, Black Truffle Butter, Parmesan, https://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=5hA4XPnT9kcL_2xODfE-_Q&userid=76vIFZcC7owykCBjMfGVXg): Delicious and flavorful, but also really rich. Although I enjoyed this dish, I'm not a huge risotto fan and wouldn't order this again.
-Garganelli Bolognese (Burrata, Basil, Calabrian Chili, https://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=MndxRu__YgoOffTYpWDKew&userid=76vIFZcC7owykCBjMfGVXg): SUPER DELICIOUS, and this was a favorite dish for everyone. The pasta was super fresh and cooked to the perfect al dente, and the sauce was amazing. The burrata was also a delicious plus- a must try!

Mains
-Meatloaf Wellington (Creamed Spinach, Orach Salad, Bordelaise Vinaigrette, https://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=HAfhJKcDSJcxPN0fDbD2Gw&userid=76vIFZcC7owykCBjMfGVXg): Not that great- I didn't like the texture of the meatloaf or the flavors. The creamed spinach was also more of a sauteed spinach. Skip!
-Pan Roasted Salmon (Clams, Bacon, Chowder Style Broth, https://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=VAjRuPsgpoKqKdggVnTS5A&userid=76vIFZcC7owykCBjMfGVXg): Not very good- the salmon pieces were tiny and overcooked/dry. The potatoes in the broth weren't cooked enough, and this dish was bland overall- skip!
-Vegetable Pot Pie (Asparagus, Peas, Confit Potato, Pearl Onions, Corn Cream, https://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=0zBPYFnZXweuycGg4ed-GQ&userid=76vIFZcC7owykCBjMfGVXg, https://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=r2LXYQaQh-DxKdo6Tny-QA&userid=76vIFZcC7owykCBjMfGVXg): Just ok. The flaky top of the pot pie was delicious, but the filling was bland and a little watery- skip!

Dessert
-'Nilla Pudding Tart ('Nilla Cookie Butter, 'Nilla Pudding, Banana, https://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=XQoi7a8K6-4kVY-085F2Pg&userid=76vIFZcC7owykCBjMfGVXg): This dessert sounded delicious, but the execution was lacking. The pudding didn't have much flavor, and the cookie butter didn't quite work with the rest of the tart- skip!
-Seasonal Fruit Crostata (Ice Cream, Brown Sugar Crumble, Mint, https://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=y10jwJ4-pKG8rtFQo3nKpw&userid=76vIFZcC7owykCBjMfGVXg): Just ok. The crostata was overbaked and hard, but at the ice cream was good. Skip!

Again, our server was amazing, and he did a great job getting us out of there in time. They do not skimp on the portions here, and we were all basically full after the pasta course. All the leftovers were sent home with one of the girls, so no food went to waste! I would definitely come back to Corridor, and look forward to having their pasta again.
author: Amy D.

description:
Probably should be 3.5.
Pros:
Outstanding services from reservation to waiter & waitress.
Monkey bread was superb no if or else, just awesome.
Quick service as we only had 1 hr 15 min before the concert starts.
Corkage charge was $20, very reasonable nowadays.


Cons:
Place is contemporary & not very intimate if you get placed on the long table upstairs instead of a 2 or 4.
Onion soup was a bit funky, not in a bad way just not the classic I always look for.  I didn't order the one with ribs but still weird.
Pork chop was some what gamy, if it's lamb it's ok.  May be too organic ?! It was still very slightly over cook, not by much, other might like it just like that.  It does not melt in your mouth so to speak, perhaps it shouldn't!

Overall was great experience for pre-concert dinner.  If the food gets up another notch, we will become regular.
author: CAScuba Y.

description:
Between work and the how quickly places seem to come and go, it's becoming increasingly difficult for me to keep up with the City's ever evolving restaurant scene.  It's easy to track the buzzier openings, but I'd be lying if I said I knew much about Corridor before coming here.  However, it wasn't hard to get excited about checking them out after reading their reviews on Yelp, including a rather glowing one from Yelp buddy Cherylynn N.!

Not to be confused with Corridor Cafe (their coffee, tea, and to-go arm), Corridor is a great spot that seems to be getting seriously overlooked.  Their location might be why (it's easy to miss, being at the bottom of a condominium tower), but it's also the reason there's plenty of street parking around (there aren't many other businesses nearby).  What's more, both the concept and the menu are very approachable - slightly elevated dishes at rather budget friendly prices for what you get.

NOTE: Not sure about their lunch service, but for dinner, we had a traditional restaurant experience, as opposed to the "order at the counter and take a seat" concept others have mentioned.

-- CALAMARI MISTO - Marinated & Fried Calamari, Smoked Potato, Harissa Aioli, and Olive Tapenade...$11
(https://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/corridor-restaurant-san-francisco-4?select=bvutmt7LjNYn7l7QIUBoCQ)
As much as I love a plate full of fried calamari, this was an awesome take on the dish.  Not only were the fried pieces crispy and delicious, but I liked how the marinated ones added a textural and flavor contrast.  Also, the dish as a whole was well seasoned, but I thought the dabs of aioli added a nice touch.

-- MONKEY BREAD - Pull-apart Bread with Cheddar Cheese, Chive OIl, and Basil Aioli...$6
(https://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/corridor-restaurant-san-francisco-4?select=Q-HVph3ul8e_a1Rih4b8eQ)
Thankfully, all of the good stuff we had heard about this dish were true!  As a whole, the bread was very light, albeit a little oily.  The crusty exterior gave way to a soft, cheesy center that was accented well by the herbaceous flavors of the chive oil and basil aioli.  Plus, it's a great value, as it was enough for the four of us to share.

-- GARGANELLI BOLOGNESE - Burrata, Basil, Calabrian Chili...$16
(https://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/corridor-restaurant-san-francisco-4?select=ZgW_pspakiEOiOzqHB3GwQ)
Several menu items caught my eye, but my pick was made as soon as I read "burrata".  The noodles had just the right bite to them and the taste of the sauce was terrific.  It could have used a little more meat and herbs, but the burrata more than made up for any shortcomings.  After all...it's BURRATA!

Besides how solid the food was, we all thought the service was great as well.  Despite a short stretch where it felt like the servers had disappeared (maybe because we were seated at a corner table upstairs?), all of the workers were warm, friendly, and very accommodating.  Plus, unlike the chaotic traffic outside on Van Ness, Corridor has a relaxed vibe that's perfect for get togethers, whether it be with friends or that special someone.

Personally, this one experience was more than enough to quickly perch Corridor high on my list of go-to spots in SF.  The food here may not have impressed like how State Bird's or Marlowe's did, but I'd definitely like to come back to try the likes of their burger and chicken parm sandwich, as well as their sister restaurants (Fat Angel, Trestle, and Stone's Throw).

FOUR AND A HALF STARS rounded down for now, but Corridor, you will see me again soon!
author: Mike L.

description:
I don't usually write reviews but this place was so good I had to make an exception. I took my parents here before a show at the Orpheum and it was such a good choice. The walk to the theater wasn't too riddled with suspicious characters and they got us in and out fast enough to get to the theater before they even opened the doors. 

The food was excellent, servings were on the smaller side but perfect for saving room for the real star of the meal: the desserts! We had the banana pudding and the chocolate desserts and both were rich and full of flavor. Service was attentive and very professional. 

I put in a reservation as opposed to walking in so that we could get seated upstairs which is nice since it's removed from prying eyes on the street. 

Definitely coming back when we come out for the next show!
author: Kristine B.

description:
Came here a few weeks ago with a friend, and it was our first time. Here is what we ordered:

*Spicy Meatballs* - tasty, juicy, flavourful. Nothing life changing, but would order again.
*Potato Leek Soup* - WOW. Delicous, rich, smoky, great flavours and textures.
Pasta: we couldn't decide which to try, so our server recommended the *Garganelli Bolognese* - one of the most satisfying pasta dishes I've had in recent memory!
*Hokkaido Scallops* - Amazing. Rich flavours, but felt light going down. Perfectly seared scallops, and the veggies, crispy rice, and soy-butter emulsion had us fighting to lick the plate.

Service was fast and friendly, and the servers made some good recommendations. We also got to meet the manager, who was very warm and welcoming.

I'll definitely be back. Probably with a bigger group, so I can try the entire menu.
author: Yasir S.

description:
*** Enjoyed ***
Creamy Corn Curry Soup - You can taste the fresh corn in this soup and it is super creamy and hearty. It hits you first with the great corn taste, and then follows that up with the tasty curry!

Had lunch here the other day, and was recommended to have the half soup half salad combo as a light lunch to get you through the rest of the day. Perfect recommendation!

With the combo, I had the Smoked Trout & Farro Salad along with the Cream soup. They were both on point, you can taste the freshness of the ingredients. The salad was very light and delicious and their vinaigrette complemented that smokey trout perfectly. And as I already mentioned above, loved their Creamy Corn soup.

Co-worker also order a shareable plate, which were the Fried Calamaris. This to me was a bit too salty, at some points, it was like biting through salted breading...

Overall it was an enjoyable lunch, healthy as well, just a little bit pricey for your average lunch though. The combo with the soup and salad was $16, and the portions are a bit tiny, although very tasty indeed.

*** Misc Info ***
-10% off for City employees
-Street Parking
-Accepts card (as well as splitting the bill)
author: Benjamin W.

description:
Always friendly service . Amazing natural light in the dining room. Chairs are a bit uncomfortable for my liking, but very minor.

The food is tasty, consistent and well worth the price! 
The Chef is creative with this take on standard dishes and the presentation of the food is on point!

I usually take my business clients here for lunch or coffee in the afternoons.

I'm so glad they are in this neighborhood!
author: Kay H.

description:
Modern & clean open air design lends itself to the straightforward yet amazingly executed fare. 
Brunch was stellar, highlights were smoked trout and apple salad, corned beef hash, soft scrambled eggs and if you leave without trying the beignets you are robbing yourself of the experience and will regret it. 
Coffee was piping hot and of great quality, mimosas and attentive service rounded out a really wonderful experience. Can't wait to comeback for dinner and am headed to sister restaurant StonesThrow tonight. Bravo!!
author: Gary FX L.

description: It was ok. The vegetarian option was risotto which gets tiresome across restaurants (and heavy). Might give it another shot some other time, as we came late on a slow night, but our party of 3 (incl 2 non-veg) just found it decent but underwhelming.
author: jml j.

description:
**Corridor Cafe has moved to Corridor Restaurant***

To be honest, i like the old location better. I get that they want to use the old cafe as a prep kitchen, but the line to order and wait for coffee is just too crazy now. Also, they raised the prices of their food!!

I come here often for my usual 16oz. coffee and the occasional sausage breakfast burrito if i'm feeling fancy. 

Baristas are super sweet and attentive. I will need to check out their happy hour soon! $5 beer and wine :)
author: Anh T.

description:
Great service..as long as  you finish in allotted time slots.  
Food aversge....
Ordered monkey bread, pan roasted salmon , Bolognese pasta dish, donut holes with lemon, chocolate pudding....all were fine, but nothing special. 
Salmon a bit dry (slightly overcooked), sample size....
Both desserts sounded much better than reality.
Monkey bread was a hit.
author: Sharine d.

description:
Nice restaurant.

Came here for dinner a few times. Located in the smack dab center of downtown SF, the location is hard to beat. The inside is decorated very well, with large open spaces and lots of seating room, and even a 2nd floor. There is an open kitchen, the dim intimate lighting.

The service is super nice. Everyone from the hostess to the bartender are all very welcoming.

The food is great. We tried the Monkey Bread, French Onion Soup, Calarmai, and Rivioli. The French Onion Soup was served hot, with lots of melted onion on top. The Monkey Bread was served hot and fresh. The Calarami portion was actually pretty big. Not bad.

There are lots of options for beer and wine. You can sample them before deciding on which to get. I got the High Octane in the end--it had pretty good hoppy taste.

Will definitely come back
author: Henry L.

description:
My friends and I were going to see Avenue Q at the New Conservatory Theater on Vanness and decided to drop by Corridor for dinner beforehand as it is literally right across the street. I would recommend calling and making reservations beforehand if you want to sit in the restaurant portion of the restaurant upstairs, as it is a smaller area than the more casual bar seating downstairs.

We showed up on time and were prompted seated at our table upstairs. We ordered two appetizers to share: the crispy falafel croquettes ($9) and monkey bread ($6), which according to Yelp is a popular item here. 

The falafel croquettes were alright; I was expecting something with potato since it was called croquette (and maybe there was), but it tasted exactly like a regular falafel to me. The monkey bread was the standout of the meal for me. The bread was still warm when served, and it was such a pleasure to rip a chunk of it out (with your hands, hence the name monkey bread) and take a big bite of the well-seasoned bread. The cheddar taste wasn't overly powerful either, which I was worried about.

For my main, I ordered the vegetable pot pie ($17). I am a sucker for pot pies and usually order it if I see it on the menu. It came out looking very promising, as it was much larger than expected and was still piping hot. However, once I started cutting into it, I realized that probably half of the pot pie was empty inside and that the size was deceiving given the amount of filling inside. I would have preferred a smaller pot pie that was fuller than a large one that's half air. The filling itself was okay, nothing really stood out except for the beets, which I thought was an interesting addition to the pot pie even though it felt like it didn't really belong. I don't think the salt was spread out evenly among the crust, as I hit a couple of areas of crust that were especially salty. Overall a very disappointing pot pie, especially considering the price tag. 

At least the service was amazing. Our server was very attentive and our glasses were never empty.
author: Dianna H.

description:
We were so excited by the menu. It looks fantastic! But looks are where it ended. We ate:

* Cheddar monkey bread: probably our least favorite dish. Immense waste of calories. It's like they took a piece of stale bread, and tried to reinvigorate it by dipping it in a vat of oil for 7 years, surrounding it with cheddar, and baking it until it somehow got even drier.

* Falafel: it was just okay. I wouldn't come here for falafel, there is much better in the area. Also, this was pure falafel, not like whatever name they fancified it with.

* Half chicken: it was a moist half chicken. Not the best, not the worst.

* Bolognese: they either didn't make this pasta fresh, or it was overcooked, but the pasta melted in your mouth -- not in a good way. It's SF folks. If I'm going out and spending $20 on $2 worth of pasta, it's not unreasonable to expect it to be home made and al dente.

I never go out of my way to write negative reviews, but none of our dishes were up to par. It's not that one or two were bad. They had a 100% failure rate. Really quite embarrassing that I brought a friend here after claiming SF has such a good food scene.

Overall, this place was overpriced for what you get, and the food was just not good. There are much better options if you just walk a little west towards Hayes Street.
author: Gil F.

description:
Stopped by for some dinner with coworkers last night and it was POPPIN. 

We were able to get seating immediately at the bar but everywhere else was filled! The ambiance of the restaurant was hip, modern, and dark but the noise level was way turnt up. I had a bit of a hard time conversing with said coworkers. 

Monkey bread: yooo-- must try! The pesto-ish dipping sauce with the cheesy brioche type pull apart bread was yummy! 
Bolognese: melting the burrata on top of a not-so-unique but otherwise pretty decent bowl of pasta = A+!

I'll need to try some other dishes, but so far pretty good. 

The service was also pretty on point. The waitress made sure my cup of water was filled. (:
author: Maggie Y.

description:
Between all the things that go on in my life, one constant recently has been dinners with Stefanie C. We probably don't get together as often as we used to, but we try and meet up and grab some dinner and hang out for a little while. 

This place has been on my list of places to try since I loved my experiences at Trestle and Stone's Throw (which are other restaurants by the same people). When we went in for dinner on a Sunday night, there weren't very many people. We ended up sitting at some of the higher tables downstairs for our dinner. 

We started with the Monkey Bread (Pull-Apart Bread with Cheddar Cheese, Chive Oil, Basil Aioli) to share. I had seen some other reviewers rave about it and I do love a monkey bread in general so we had to try it. It's really good. The aioli was delicious with it and definitely not enough was given - we should have asked for more. 

I ended up getting the garganelli bolognese with burratta, basil, and calabrian chili. Actually I ordered it because of the burratta (my favorite cheese) and it was a large portion. This was actually enough for two full meals. Highly recommend. 

I'll definitely have to drop by again if I'm in the area - great food, good service, and modern appeal. 

Protip: monkey bread.
author: Nina Y.

description:
I'm still trying to figure out the theme of this place. With no visible sign on the outside, we still managed to stumble across this hidden gem. It has sleek, clean and modern interior. The first floor is spacious with high tables to fit a party of 6. The second floor is a bit more intimate. 

We made reservations for 7:30 pm and notice how packed the upstairs floor was. Reservations are always a good idea. I initially noticed their happy hour menu and was sad that we were past due the 3-6pm deals. HH entails $5 beer, wine & cocktails! I'll definitely be back for that. 

After careful consideration, my boyfriend and I decided to share the monkey bread, french soup, and garganelli bolognese. We completely underestimated how filling our carb-dominant dinner would be. We started off with the monkey bread which was warm, savory roll of bread with chive oil on top. Crunchy on the outside and fluffy on the inside. The inside of the bread was as soft as a sponge cake. Next, we had the French onion soup with a large helping of melted cheese. Not too sure what kind of cheese they use but it was very mild and perfect with the short rib and crostini. The chunks of short rib would literally melt in your mouth. Lastly, the bolognese which was perfecto! The pasta was cooked al dente and I liked how it had a strong taste of basil. 

Best part of all is that we barely broke our bank with this meal. All of the dishes are decently priced. I will definitely come back to try their "square" meals and need to try their desserts that everyone kept ordering!
author: Rachelle Y.

description:
*** In Short ***

Casual, tasty eats, from the folks that brought you Stones Throw and Trestle.

*** In Depth ***

Those familiar with the above two restaurants should already know what to expect from yet another fine Hi Neighbor Hospitality Group establishment: quality food, but, in particular, tasty, tasty pastas. The good news? Corridor is no different, serving up the pastas we've come to love, among many other dishes, including some items pulled directly from Stones Throw. The better news? Their entrees are priced much more affordably, mostly falling between $15-20. Oh, AND commuting to or parking here is notably easier. And... well, there's no bad news, so, what are you waiting for?

Their appetizers aren't bad, but really, don't miss out on the pastas: their sweet corn risotto and asparagus carbonara were especially delightful.

***Accessibility Info***

Venue - While the downstairs isn't particularly wheelchair friendly, minus the shorter counter at the bar, their upstairs has much more accessible seating, and is accessible via a lift towards the left of the main ordering area downstairs.

Bathroom - Didn't try them.
author: Johnny W.

description:
We stopped here before seeing a show at the Bill Graham Auditorium.  This spot is conveniently located near a ton of venues and the food did not disappoint. The monkey bread is on the 7x7 Big Eats list, so we had to try this place out.

We arrived during happy hour and the nice thing about this place is that you can enjoy happy hour drink prices even in the dining room. 

Our server was super friendly, attentive and thoughtful. He asked us, first thing, if we had any food-allergies and my man-friend said he really doesn't like onions. For the rest of the meal, we didn't have to ask for no onions (we actually forgot to, he usually eats around them) and every dish that came out had the onions removed and the guy who brought the food would make a joke about having added extra onions. 

We ordered 2 glasses of wine and the monkey bread while we looked over the menu and decided what to order. The monkey bread was soo good, worth every bite and the two toppings were just amazing together. We also ordered the spicy meatballs - not that spicy, and I am a wimp when it comes to spicy, the little gems salad (one complaint was that the avocados were a little under-ripe, but they tasted good, just too hard to cut with just your fork, and the calamari misto. All items were on the starters list. The portion sizes were very plentiful, for being starters, good bang for the buck. Between the two of us, we didn't even eat everything!

I would definitely go back and try some of the other dishes on their entree list and I will definitely go back more hungry!
author: La Tache T.

description:
Came here for dinner and drinks before our Avenue Q show.  The location is convenient and the food is great.  Once you enter, you order and pay for your food before finding your seat.  If you're lucky, you can either grab a seat at the bar or at the communal tables, otherwise it helps to make reservations during the holiday months. 

We ordered the monkey bread, lasagna and happy hour wine.  First of all, the monkey bread was delicious.  The bread is fluffy with semi crispy cheese on the bottom.  Did I mention the chive oil dip is to die for?!  The lasagna entrees were delicious especially on a cold evening.  It had a nice ratio of meat to sauce.  I especially loved how my cube of lasagna was wrapped in a lasagna sheet, covered with light sauce and cheese.  It held together so beautifully!  It especially paired well with my happy hour Cabernet Sauvignon.  The Field Recordings "Neverland" was so drinkable and smooth, I ended up with 2 glasses!

Service is on point here.  You can still have delicious food and wine even when you're on a time pinch.  In our case, the communal tables were only available for 45 minutes before the next table (reservations) were to be seated.
author: Sandra L.

description: The asparagus risotto is divine.  I also came during Happy Hour (3-6pm) and wine was more than half off.  Service is excellent.  Very respectful and accommodating.  Great place to eat before a performance at the Symphony, Opera or Ballet.
author: Ted B.

description: Good restaurant option when you are catching a show (opera, symphony, jazz center, Orpheum).  Food, service and ambiance are all good.  Highly recommend the Crispy duck confit and the crostata with sorbet. Appetizers are also tasty (meatballs and calamari).
author: Andrew S.

description: Sunday was the first time I had been to this restaurant.  The appetizers and hamburgers were perfect.  The cocktails were original and well prepared.  The chocolate dessert was good too.  Our waiter knew his job, too.  All was excellent.
author: Emily G.

description:
Upscale fast casual seems to be a good description of this spot. Nice modern atmosphere and a lot of space, with friendly service. The food is where Corridor lost me. 

We had the monkey bread, meatballs, bolognese and veggie pot pie. Dish reviews as follows:

-Monkey bread: I don't get the hype. Fluffy in the way of wonderbread, and the aioli was pretty flavorless, in my opinion. Still, people near us were raving about it, so this could be just me. 2/5
-Meatballs: would recommend these. The sauce is great and the tomatoes and sweet peppers add a touch of zing to it all. Solid 5/5
-Bolognese: sauce was good (same as meatballs if I'm not mistaken). Burrata was nice as well. Unfortunately the pasta was way overdone. 3/5
-Pot pie: the crust was nice and crisp, but otherwise would not recommend or order again. Rather bland and otherwise nondescript. Not a good adjective to be attached to food. 2/5

Like I said, great service. We might have just ordered wrong. Try if you're curious!
author: Lauren C.

description:
YAHOO!!! one more great restaurant courtesy of the Stone's Throw/Trestle/Fat Angel/Corridor Cafe team.

LOVE this place - came here pre-theatre on a Wed. We got there around 5:20, there were plenty of communal tables downstairs (I had called the day before there were no reservations upstairs) The happy hour is awesome,  ALL cocktails (all glasses of wine)  $5 until 6pm. So the two of us had 1 Pimm's cocktail and 4 glasses of wine.

I don't really understand the concept of ordering your drinks when you first come in at the counter - THEN it is regular waiter service - but heck - I have no problem with it. Our main server John (who was ADORABLE BTW) was so friendly, and just paced our meal perfectly.

I had scoured the Yelp reviews and photos and had my order ready. We stared with the savory Monkey bread and the carrot salad (I wished they had the burrata/tomato salad, but understand that tomato season is gone (sigh!).

Then we were to have the French onion soup & the Meatballs.  ALL of it -  just exactly the perfection of homey/a little unexpected/flawless seasoning treats that I have come to expect from my favorite restaurant "chain" - are they a chain now - how many is a chain? 

I have not yet been to the café, or Stone's Throw (but to all the others, Trestle is my favorite - I just got a friend of mine a job where I work, she is taking me to Stone's Throw as a thank you. Then I will be just one little café away from the goal of all 5.

The bill was around $70 (plus tip) - I wanted dessert but was too full. I would have been happy to have split a monkey bread, gotten a soup (not sharing) and 1/2 of a dessert. Next time!

LOVE this place.
author: Amy W.

description:
Dinner review. 

Monkey cheese bread - 4/5
Flatbread dip trio - 2/5
Roasted sunchokes - 3/5
Meatloaf wellington - 3/5

Upscale counter ordering --

Overall, ""I've experienced better."
author: Mark O.

description:
Corridor was a pleasant surprise.  Each dish had its own twist and surprise:
+ Calamari Misto - tender marinated calamari with a light breading. Delicious piquant olives and sauce.
+ Little Gem salad - fresh and crisp.  The Dijon dressing added a nice spice.
+ Fettuccine Carbonara - wonderful textures. Really appreciated the small crispy lemon croutons. 
+ Brioche doughnuts - dusted in lavender sugar and served with a very nice lemon curd.

Attentive knowledgeable service.
Would recommend for before or after Civic Center events.
author: Scott A.

description: Monkey bread and salmon main were both really good. Burger was ok - not bad but nothing to rave about either (and meat was overcooked).
author: Laura D.

description:
Came on a busy Sunday night right before a SF Symphony performance. Service was polite and fairly quick given the crowd. Seating is quasi-communal (2 parties of 2 on a 6-top), which led to some confusion where the other party's soup went on our check, but it was resolved promptly.

Monkey bread and french onion soup are amazing, I'd come back just to have those for a snack with some drinks. We also split the pumpkin risotto and duck confit - the duck was quite salty, we could have used more of the berry sauce to cut the saltiness. The pumpkin risotto was rich, creamy, and delicious - I didn't think the red wine onions went with the risotto well but I am not a big fan of onions in general, so that's probably just me. 

I hope to be back soon and would def recommend this spot prior to a show at Davies or the opera house!
author: Julia L.

description:
Went here for lunch for my boss bday. It was awesome! Making reservation for 7 was easy. They answer the phone through out the day! Yes! 

The food were awesome. Money bread is to die for. Wtf is that stuff!? Omg it melts in your mouth. Have you ever ate a piece of bread, so light, so fluffy, so garlicky but cheesy at the same time you dont know what went in your mouth and all you want to do is to get MOOOOOOREEEEEEE. That is the Money Bread!

Salad and soups are great portioned and prices. Everything is super fresh. I had the asparagus soup and the cobb salad. they were both great EXCEPT THE CHICKEN IN MY COBB. that's chicken? It tasted dry, unseasoned, chewy, and overall didn't taste like chicken. everyone else seemed to enjoy their food. I will be back! this time, I aim to get the Veggie Pot Pie and French Onion soup. Oh and MONEY BREAD!
author: Kris J.

description:
My wife, mother-in-law and I had dinner here with a few friends before seeing Hamilton.  We had a great experience and our waiter was really cool and gave us insight scoops on what to get and what not to get.  We had a reservation so checking in downstairs was a bit odd as we didn't know what to do with our ticket/key.  But once we got upstairs it was all figured out.  

Definitely get the monkey bread and meatballs.  I had the duck confit for my main meal and it was awesome.
author: Blake B.

description: Gosh i thought i wrote a review.  The monkey bread was hand size, very delicate and soft with pesto flavor. You peel a bun at a time like a flower petal.  Service was great, recommendations given.  My table buddy got chicken which was huge (think leftover lunch).  I had garganelli bolignese pasta (al dente).  Got carbo-ed.  We finished off with ice cream with raspberry sauce and pecans.  Just ok. Downstairs was crowded with happy hour peps.  We got a seat in the corner upstairs which was good since we were able to a have a conversation.  Beware of single restroom downstairs with sliding door beside the hostess.  No indication when it is occupied, just that the door won't open.  Upstairs is the other only restroom.  There is definitely a wind tunnel getting into the door on Oak st.side.
author: Helen L.

description:
This place is great for HH drinks and light bites, but every time I've come here for a 'meal' it has been a pretty underwhelming experience with fractured, slow, but friendly service. 

I had an exceptionally unimpressive lunch today, and was bemused by the absence of servers. I had to ask for our next course and for the bill, which to me signals that they're either behind, understaffed, or both. 

Lunch consisted of french onion soup (which bizarrely included whole cherry tomatoes and cubed chunks of ham) and a trout and farro salad (pretty presentation but this was under-seasoned and lemon would have helped). 

It seems they don't know if they want to be a posh lunch counter or a table service bistro. I may visit again, but only for drinks.
author: Nina N.

description: Modern atmosphere and good service, accompanied by good food. It's a limited menu, but make sure to order the monkey bread!
author: Rob S.

description:
I made a reservation via Open Table but had to shift the time due to traffic driving in from Napa and the folks on the phone were very kind and easy to work with. I wish I was in the mood for drinking as their beverages looked amazing, even the nonalcoholic offerings.

The food is divine. Things that you wouldn't make at home or wouldn't make with such attention to flavor profiles and presentation. Don't skip dessert - the fruit tart was a star. For our meal we sampled the duck confit with black Forbidden rice and I also had the sweet corn soup with shrimp. Stunning. The kind of meal where you eat slow to make each bite last longer.

The atmosphere is kinda stark, especially upstairs but the service was warm. Go with friends so you can try as much as possible.
author: Elisabeth B.

description: Although I don't remember the salmon or scallop dish (not saying it wasn't good), I can't forget the monkey bread and the happy hour priced red wine.  It is worth a trip solely for this bread.  It is on my top 2 list of breads, only second to Rutherford Grills cornbread.  This is bucket list bread!
author: Dianne M.

description:
Came to Corridor last night for a pre-show dinner at Symphony Hall.  Loved the clean lines and openness of the place - the high ceilings made for a laidback vibe - we had reservations & were taken upstairs where there were individual tables & more of an intimate feel - perfect for a nice catch up w/ good friends!

Started w/ a Happy Hour wines - whites & reds alike were delish & they also had cocktails - all for $5......score!

Appies included the monkey bread - nice crispy cheese on top & pesto spread & also the falafel croquettes - small falafels w/ a dill sauce - very yummy.  Nice crunch & crumbly inside!

Entrees included the English Pea Risotto for sis & me.  I was over the moon to find they served it w/ truffle butter instead of lemon or mint - which most pea dishes tend to pair & those 2 are on my naughty list.....so creamy & tender.  This was almost like eating a polenta & this is a very good thing!  Lots of fresh peas - yum!

Mr got the Veggie Pot Pie & the crust was so light & flaky w/ lots of mushrooms & carrots - the flavors were outstanding - this also came w/ a side wedge salad & it was crisp & vinegary is an awesome way

BFF got the Duck Confit - grilled peaches & bitter chard provided a plethora of flavor balancing action going on & while he loved it, he loved our risotto even better

Not a group to pass on desserts, indulged in the Banana Tart - cookie butter & pastry cream w/ fresh bananas - very yummy but also have to say you put cookie butter on anything & I'm gonna love it

BFF got the Brownie Sundae & it was a nice parfait of deliciousness

Would come back to Corridor in a heartbeat for a pre-show meal - this place is awesomeness
author: Adrienne G.

description:
Really impressed by the food here. The French onion soup is seriously upper echelon -- the salty tangy broth is delicious, and I liked the big chunks of short rib they include in it. 

The other dishes we had (garganelli bolognese and roast salmon) were also good, and pretty reasonable for sharing.

Ambiance is kind of wonky - looks like an upscale sandwich store for Twitter employees, and its large windows look out on a not-so-picturesque intersection of Van Ness. There's an upstairs seating area that looked a bit more intimate, I'd recommend trying to get up there if possible.
author: Ryan D.

description: Came in for a quick dinner before a lecture at the Nourse theater and I am so glad we did! They have a great Happy Hour till 6 and we got to try some great rose for only $5! based off of the yelp reviews we opted for the monkey bread, vegetable salad and pasta carbonara. The salad for me was the star of the evening, light and refreshing but also very flavorful. The other two dishes were also excellent and the service and ambiance were the cherry on top!
author: Rachel N.

description:
This place is delicious. I've come here twice and it's always very popular. The first time I came for happy hour and got a glass of wine for $5! Such a good deal, considering they are usually $10-$12.  We started with the monkey bread and the calamari, both which were delicious. The monkey bread especially was so amazing.

Both times I got the salmon, which is delicious. It's cooked to a perfect medium rare and a great size. I got 2x brussels sprouts the second time and no cauliflower just because I love brussels sprouts.

I will definitely come back here. Everything is at least 4/5
author: Jenna G.

description:
Very nice slick modern ground floor space in new office building. Food is excellent from a limited menu. Very large portions. Wine by the glass is mediocre but not too expensive.

Nice happy hour.

I would recommend it for what we did which was dinner before the opera. Nothing wrong other than wine selection.
author: Elroy E.

description: Amazing place - the burger is killer. The drinks are well selected, the desserts are expertly made. Tucked away, on its own, this restaurant was a perfect date spot. The service was impeccable !
author: Shounak C.

description:
