Had lunch with my family here today.  It was really really good.  The ambiance was nice, floor to ceiling windows, the service was good.  the food was really great.  The best was the monkey bread and the pumpkin risotto.  Something in that risotto was really special, although it was kinda small portions.  

I had the shrimp roll.  The bread was good, nice presentation.  The shrimp are on the smaller side.  Fries are pretty good.

Came out to about $135 with tax and tip for 6 people.  Not too bad:)
author: Monica L.

description:
This may be one of my new favorite restaurants in SF! It's just so beautiful in its simplicity--food and service are great and you can't beat the quality and ambiance for the price point!

Came here for lunch today to catch up with a colleague. Location is great--close to BART at civic center and muni metro at Van Ness. Super close to the theaters/opera house too. 

The space is perfect. So so airy and bright! The downstairs has huge windows and counter seating. The upstairs is a bit more intimate. Open kitchen and great colors/lighting.

You order at the front and are given this electronic thing that looks like one of those vibrating coasters at other restaurants but it never lights up/vibrates. We couldn't actually figure out what it's for exactly since we had a server bring our food to the table anyway. Payment is after the meal like a regular sit-down restaurant. I guess the time savings is not taking the order at the table?

Complexity of service model notwithstanding, the menu is focused and full of things I'd love to return to try. Cuisine is definitely "new American." Small bites (shareables), Salads, soup, pastas, flatbreads, burger, chicken, salmon (proper meals). 

We ordered the monkey bread to start. I had the chicken cobb salad which was huge and my colleague had the tomato burrata salad (which is technically a starter but was a good vegetarian lunch option). We also both had the La Mill coffee which was presented beautifully and really tasty (first time trying this particular roaster). Everything tasted great! Food came out extremely fast and presentation was really impressive for "fast casual." 

Service was grade-A and aforementioned ambiance was perfect. Love love loved everything about this lunch experience and definitely will return for dinner. Also want to try their cafe next door based on the deliciousness of the monkey bread.
author: Semuteh F.

description:
Casual spot with a stellar wine/beer happy hour and on point food.

Food: 4, Service: 4, Atmosphere: 4
Cost to worth it rating: 4 (entrees mostly around $15)
Return worthiness: yes

Highlights:
- Leek bread pudding: French onion soup on a plate with raclette cheese. 4.5 stars 
- French onion soup: secret ingredient is short rib on top of the usual oniony cheesy goodness. 4 stars
- Monkey bread: soft brioche version topped with chives. 4 stars 
- Duck confit chicory salad: huge plate with the radish type base and shredded pieces of duck and cubes of fresh crunchy pear and nuts. Textures galore that melded well together. 4 stars
- Spicy meatballs: beautiful plate with the meatballs hidden under shaved Parmesan, peppers, and basil in a nice tomato sauce. 4 stars
- Happy hour: any wine by the glass, beer on tap, or one of their signature cocktails for only $5! Quality wine at that and goes for $10+ a glass. Don't even have to be in the bar--can get it at your table. 

Lowlights:
- Happy hour ordering rules: must be finished with a drink to be able to order another. Typically places all you have to do is order before the time is up which we did for our second round but then were told the mentioned rules after the fact. 

Liked this small spot and would come back--especially if seeing a show at the Orpheum or wanting a wine happy hour.
author: Eve K.

description:
The food and service is stellar! The ambiance, however, is kind of weird. The space is pretty sterile in comparison to the comfort quality of the food. The restaurant is in the front of an office complex, the open air room, high ceilings, minimalist chairs/tables and glass front makes it feel pretty cold. Almost like a cafeteria.

Yet he food - the food is the true star. It is so well crafted, local ingredients, they obviously share the chef's personal flair. The food makes up for it. Aside from the strange space, I loved our lunch. I got the french onion soup and smoked trout salad, coworkers got the cauliflower soup and chopped salad and pasta bolognese. Every person raved about each of their dishes! I will be back for lunch to go, to take back to my office.
author: Steenie K.

description: The croissant with eggs, creme fraiche and cheese was delicious and service was friendly and fast! Planning to come back and try out other menu items.
author: L. W.

description:
If Little Gem represents the face of new-style casual dining in the city, then Corridor Restaurant must represent the other side, I mean like the posterior if you know what I mean. And I think you do. I didn't much mind the order-at-the-counter concept at Little Gem, so I was trying to figure out why it was bugging me at Corridor. I think it was the presumption I felt from the staff that this is the service model I wanted at an upscale restaurant when in fact, I would have preferred a bit more conversation with the server at the register. With a young hipster couple heaving sighs of entitlement behind us, Jamie W. and I found it hard to get relaxed when it felt like we needed to make several decisions quickly.

Now I suppose we could have taken ourselves out of the line and really studied the menu among ourselves, but as we recited our order, it still felt like ordering a burrito bowl at Chipotle. Chef Jason Halverson and partner Ryan Cole would have you believe this is the future of upscale dining and probably tell you to get over it because mounting labor costs and exorbitant rents make it impossible to provide traditional table service anymore. OK, I get it. I'll just take my number upstairs to our table and shut up. We started with one of the "Shareables", the $6 Monkey Bread, a fairly reasonable price for the familiar pull-apart bread filled with melted cheddar cheese and accompanied by a chive dipping sauce (photo:  http://bit.ly/29Jz70p).

It was tasty enough though personally I didn't think the dipping sauce was necessary since the bread was so pliably oily. For his entree, Jamie definitely got the better deal with the $19 Half-Roast Chicken, which was a plentiful portion but even with the garlic chicken jus, it was a rather generic treatment given any number of rotisserie chicken operations around town. He wisely chose the crushed Yukon gold potatoes and the asparagus a la plancha as his sides (photo: http://bit.ly/29MBq0Z). Mine was an unmitigated flop, the $26 Beef Ribeye, apparently whole-roasted with a thyme and black pepper jus. Not only was it lukewarm but for medium-rare, it was overdone and sliced to the consistency of chewy roast beef. Expensive cafeteria fare.

I also went for the asparagus but with the tomato-braised green beans instead of the potatoes (photo: http://bit.ly/29A2nbS). Never will I order the ribeye again, especially since it was the most expensive item on the regular menu. To pacify my spirits, I ordered the $9 Stones Throw Pimm's, which they aren't kidding is a low-proof cocktail as there was barely any giddy-up to what is normally one of my favorite libations even with vermouth and ginger beer reportedly in the mix (photo: http://bit.ly/29A2oMQ). The volume was getting awfully high with the neighboring party of obnoxious tech-heads particularly indifferent to the decibel levels they were generating. The three $8 dessert options just weren't enough for us to stay any longer than we had to.

FOOD - 2 stars...surprisingly disappointing execution given the pedigree
AMBIANCE - 2.5 stars...the bar is nicer than the noisy dining room upstairs with the plastic chairs particularly uncomfortable
SERVICE - 2 stars...the not-quite waiter upstairs was attentive enough but otherwise...
TOTAL - 2 stars...just think the attitudes at Little Gem are more in line with this order-at-the-counter concept we all have to get used to
author: Ed U.

description:
The San Francisco food scene has gotten ostentatious and in some cases, offensively overpriced. Don't get me wrong, I like fine dining and it has its place (for special occasions) but there's so many new [non-fine dining] restaurants in the city that seem to only be catering to new tech money.

I won't name names but two weeks ago, I dined at a restaurant that charges $6 for carrot soup, for a sh*t you not: one shot worth. And, there's a newish restaurant nearby in Mid-Market where my friend and I paid $11 for three lettuce leaves adorned with 3 dots of dressing.

What the PHUCK is up with this pretentious bullsh*t?! 

Ladybugs eat more lettuce than that! 

Enter Corridor from the Hi Neighbor Group (Fat Angel, Stones Throw, Trestle, and Corridor Cafe). I've dined at all their other restaurants and I've consistently found that they offer solid food with healthy portions at reasonable prices served by a professional and a hospitable staff. Corridor is no different. 

They grand opened today at the ground level of the 100 Van Ness luxury apartment building. They're open for lunch, happy hour (3 pm - 6 pm everyday), and dinner. The concept is "fast fine dining" and is a good option for nearby theatergoers. 

The menu is New American and American Comfort Food with items like Falafel Croquettes, Corn Chowder, Crispy Duck Confit Salad, Pastas, Ribeye, Burger, French Dip, and Daily Specials (Hello, Porchetta and Braised Short Ribs!). Beer, wine, and loophole cocktails only. During HH (3 pm - 6 pm everyday), all draft beer, wine by the glass, and cocktails are $5. 

Upon walking in, you're greeted by a hostess. You order at the register, they swipe your credit card, and you're given a buzzer. You then seat yourself: downstairs in the bar or in a communal table, or upstairs in the mezzanine area (counter seats overlook Van Ness). Once you're seated, it's a full service restaurant. Your friendly server will take your buzzer, serve you water, deliver your food, and you can order additional items from him/her (e.g. extra booze or dessert). There's an automatic 15% gratuity added to your bill which is more than fair.

If you're in a rush and order multiple items, make sure to tell the cashier to fire your entire order, otherwise your meal will be coursed out. 

I stopped by today for a quick bite before going home. I can never order just one thing so I started with the Corn Chowder w/ cornbread madeleines ($9): http://bit.ly/2917QTa. Poured tableside, the corn chowder was velvety smooth and the plump corn kennels gave a nice pop of sweetness. The addition of the potato cubes is substantial enough for a light lunch or dinner. Minor gripe: it was a tad too salty for my taste. The accompanying cornbread madeleines were piping hot and carblicious - really enjoyed the salty bits of bacon. 

I also ordered the Garganelli Bolognese w/ burrata, basil, calabrian chili ($16): http://bit.ly/29dKsnW. The pasta was perfectly al-dente and blanketed with a robust meat sauce. At first, I thought it was bit too salty but the soft, milky burrata really helped temper the saltiness. 

Unfortunately, I had to drive home afterwards so I couldn't partake in their $5 HH drinks. Instead, I opted for their Top Hat: Ginger Beer, Cucumber, Lime, and Mint ($4.50): http://bit.ly/29dL3pG. Really refreshing and recommended for ginger lovers. 

I plan to return later this week to try other items on the menu so stay tuned!
author: Cherylynn N.

description:
If you want to dine in a large space, you have found it.  The restaurant occupies 2 levels, more of a loft second dining area.   I was seat on the second level, counter table overlooking the first level.   Very nice.   

For brunch, my bestie and I both had the burger.   Mines was medium rare and it was cooked to point. What really did shine with the burger was not the burger itself, but the fries. The fries were cooked perfectly crisp. It has been a long time since I had nice crisp season fries. 

I did like the burger, as the cheese went well with it. Highly fatty and delicious   

The seating is unique as I was given a token to give to the server on the second floor after I checked in downstairs. I guess it frees up the host position, allowing it to be a multi-functional job for the server.
author: Marck N.

description:
I went for a quick lunch at the bar and enjoyed the atmosphere, great menu selections, and super attentive and friendly service. 
The bartender/server made sure my salad was to my liking and was enthusiastic about my experience. I will definitely go back and try Corridor for dinner with a friend -- it's hip and happening.
author: Jay R.

description:
Love this restaurant. It's at the bottom of the nice condominiums, 100 van ness.

I would say it's a good spot to go on a chill night. It appears fancy but isn't really.

I ordered a salmon salad like thing that wasn't very good, but the monkey bread was delicious! Highly recommend that!
author: Nadia H.

description:
This review is for the NEW cafe that opened inside the restaurant. Corridor Cafe moved into the restaurant this week and it's awesome.

The restaurant already had the BEST happy hours in town and great food. Now they have a really comfortable coffee situation in the morning and free wi-fi!

Coffee made by pros = latte art and love. SoCal friends will recognize the LaMill coffee - I think this the only NorCal LaMill spot (?)and fresh pastries from Firebrand Bread. New full breakfast offerings too... I hope this becomes weekend brunch soon :)
author: Arianna P.

description: Great food, love their vanilla latte!   It's a very nice, casual place!  Great service and nice atmosphere.  I will definitely go back here again!
author: Marietta G.

description:
Been here twice, once for a work lunch, and once for a work dinner.

Both times, the food has been excellent, but the service and the rate at which food came out of the kitchen was slow. Reservations are also relatively easy to get. 

I love the monkey bread, meatballs, and the salmon. Would highly recommend those items. 

I will definitely come back for some excellent food when I'm in the area. 

Pro tip: Definitely don't come here super hungry (like your stomach feels like it will eat itself). You will wait a bit for the food, but the food quality and taste make up for it.
author: Carolyn Z.

description: Nice addition to the civic center area. Upstairs and downstairs seating. Recommend upstairs if want quieter seating area. Attentive service and when they messed up on an order they brought a starter at no charge so one of us wasn't eating with the others. Reasonably priced entrees. Would recommend the onion soup and the pasta dishes. Would make another visit if have a show in the area and would recommend.
author: Heather L.

description: Been here 2 times before shows.  We had good service each time and the food was solid.  If you go, ask to sit upstairs.  We have be at the table/bar overlooking the giant windows.  Be prepared for a terrible parking situation.
author: Dawn R.

description:
Just ate here last night for a graduation celebration!
If you have a large group - ask for a table upstairs - they have an elevator and bathroom upstairs.  We started with the monkey bread - absolutely delicious - loved the sauce and little Jem salad which is huge! We ordered 2 of each for table to share. For entrees - we ordered the salmon, chicken, and steak which were all delicious and pretty large portions.  For dessert - we ordered one of each - incredible!  The service was great - very nice waiter - not snooty at all. Great location to the shows!
author: Joanne C.

description:
I really enjoyed this place! I think it's a great restaurant to come to for date night or to catch up with friends. There are two levels, I think the bottom level is for walk-ins and the upstairs is for parties that made a reservation. Since we made a reservation, we were seated upstairs which was smaller than the lower level, but had more of a romantic vibe. The lower level was a lot more casual, with high top tables and bar style seating. 

90% of their drink menu was beer & wine. The food menu was smaller compared to most places, but offered a great variety of options and had many different flavor profiles. My friend and I started with the Crispy Falafel Croquettes. This was a tad bit misleading since croquettes have potato in them, but these ones didn't. It was a normal falafel. Came with 6 pieces, topped with red onion, cucumber, and a creamy Tzatziki sauce. The falafel was good. Nothing outstanding, but I appreciated that it wasn't dry and had great seasoning. The Tzatziki sauce was very good too.

For dinner we ordered the Walnut Pesto & Polenta Ravioli Pasta, and the Stones Throw's Da Burga. The ravioli was very good. The noodle tasted like it was homemade. I also liked the crispy kale and pomegranate toppings. It added a unique flavor to the dish and gave it a nice crunch. The burger was smaller in size, but very filling because the meat patty was thick. The bun was fluffy, fries were crunchy, and came with a great aioli for dipping. 

Overall great dining experience. Food was yummy and reasonably priced. Service was fast and the staff is very attentive. Looking forward to coming back and trying their lunch menu!
author: Chisholm T.

description:
Sometimes innovations and disruption are really spectacular.  Sometimes they are not.  Unfortunately, Corridor's "innovative" approach to restaurant process and flow are less than spectacular.  In fact, it seems like they have taken the least efficient parts of different service/flow concepts and merged them together for Corridor.  Or it's schizophrenic and can't decide if it wants to be casual and quick or a sit down place w table service.

It's counter service, but they go to "reserve" your table while you read the menu.  While it's nice to know you have a seat staked out, if you've already had time to decide what you'd like, you are left waiting for them to return and take your order.  Then, they take your order but start a tab rather than having you pay at the counter which leads to inefficiencies at the end of the meal.

They give you a table flasher/beeper thing like you would get at TGI Friday's or similar to tell you when your table is ready.  At Corridor, however, it's a nicer looking flasher/beeper and is for your server to know where to bring your food. I suspect this set up probably works equally well to the number-on-a-stick approach. Not likely more, or less, efficient.

Unfortunately, when 30 minutes have passed and no one has come by to let you know your food is, indeed, coming, it's hard not to wonder if the gadget flashing on the table is working.  Can the servers actually see it, since it's flat on the table?  How do they know to bring your food to *your* flasher and not to someone else's?  Is someone eating my duck confit salad right now?!  Yes, some minor panic may start to set in...

When the food finally arrived, I found my duck confit salad to be quite delicious. It was just a couple more dollars than salads I usually get near my downtown office, but much larger and included a lot of duck.  It was billed as duck confit w chicories, so I knew what I was getting.  I do think adding one non-bitter green would further enhance the flavor.  As I started eating, I thought that it was too bad that the food quality was marred by the strange service concept...or was it?  

My friend's pot pie was...something.  It had a lovely crust on top of its cute, generously-sized cast iron skillet.  Certainly promising at first glance.  Upon first bite, my friend was met with a fairly dry filling that wasn't very, uh, filling.  Ordinarily, pot pie has a good amount of bechamel or other gravy-like sauce and lots of veggies and chicken.  This was a mushroom pot pie, so no chicken expected, but my friend and I definitely expected to see a generous portion of veggies/mushrooms and sauce to go with the tasty crust.  We think if she had pulled the crust off completely to count the bits inside, it would have been about 10 pieces of potato and mushrooms.  Certainly, not the warm, comforting, filling experience expected from pot pie.

Since you pay at the table rather than at the counter when you order, we had to flag down our server to get the check.  Not a big deal, but while we were pretty sure we had the right person, it was hard to tell bc there wasn't any one person who seemed to really be responsible for our table.  Paying was fairly speedy, but not as efficient as if we had simply paid at the counter.

Ambiance: 3.5 stars. The decor is quite attractive but all high tops and hard surfaces.  Due to the hard surfaces, it is extremely loud.  Sitting across from my friend, I felt like I had to yell at her to have a conversation.  

Value: 3 stars. The food itself was mixed.  While my salad was a good value, my friend's pot pie definitely was not.  Other people's food at our communal table appeared to be more along the lines of my salad in terms of value.

Service: I can't even give it a star rating.  I can't decide if it was poor service or not.  Kind of not, but such a weird service concept.

Would I go back?  I enjoy seeing performances at the Opera House and it's nice to have another pre-performance option.  I won't go out of my way to go to Corridor, but I wouldn't be opposed to trying other things on the menu.  Now that I know how it works, I might find it less strange, but overall, I prefer to not need instructions on how to "use" a restaurant.
author: Sara E.

description: Friendly service. Garganelli Bolognese's spicy sauce was a pleasure the eat.  Pasta cooked just right to a good degree of chewiness. Blend of tomatoes, beef and cheese was fun to taste.
author: Peter K.

description: The duck was great the only reason I give this place three stars is because the rice the duck was sitting on was complete mush and was to sweet. Which made it impossible to eat. Beautiful atmosphere. Wonderful wine selection.
author: Meleaha M.

description:
Solid four stars for the value, location, and quality of the food. The restaurant is conveniently located close to the San Francisco Ballet, Symphony, and Bill Graham Auditorium. There was a great selection of wine and beer with awesome happy hour prices. I would definitely recommend Corridor if you're in the area or looking for a hip dinner or drink before a performance.

[Food]
I had the French Onion Soup, Monkey Bread, and Meatballs. I really recommend the French Onion Soup and Monkey Bread, both were well priced and tasty. The French Onion Soup is definitely on the stronger oniony side, but that's what I enjoy with my French Onion Soups. Monkey Bread was also cheesy and warm. I would pass on the Meatballs as they were a bit overcooked. 

[Service]
My waiter was super friendly and attentive! I couldn't remember his name, but my dining companion was late by 30 minutes and he definitely made me feel less annoyed. 

[Decor]
Very hip setup with larger happy hour tables on the bottom floor and a separate more private dining area on the second floor.
author: Alice Z.

description: Love this place kind of alot going on which is to be expected being it's on Van Ness right off of Market basically but food is bomb. . .well I only ever get the burgers and fries lol the people that work the make this place GREAT just nice chil professional employees! I would definitely say you haven't tried it you should!
author: Keno M.

description:
I'm not a fan of the furniture, especially the seats. They felt like I was sitting on/in a shovel. I don't like ordering at the counter - especially when prices are fairly expensive. I'm not sure if they don't normally have wait service because the counter employee requested that we pay at the table.

Given the above, I was honestly expecting yet another overpriced mediocre to pre-fab food restaurant.

Then the food arrived: corn soup, meatballs and a burger. The soup knocked our socks off! The flavours were sublime. It was culinary perfection and in the most unlikely of places.

The meatballs were as good as my Aunt Millie's. The burger was honestly up there in competition / on par with the best.

If the food is this good, 5 stars are in order and the rest can be forgiven. The staff were great.
author: Bulldog W.

description:
This is a new favorite for dinner.
Corridor is an excellent addition to the Hi Neighbor restaurant family, and I like it more than Stone's Throw and Trestle, its sister restaurants, because the food overall was of a consistently very good (and better) quality than at its counterparts, and the service upstairs for our reservation was attentive and friendly. The ambience was nice, and the four of us and all enjoyed our dishes. The monkey bread, the meatballs, the broccolini (finally, a broccolini that's cooked the right way and not bitter/chewy), the burger, the salmon and the pasta carbonara were all hits. I am looking forward to coming back here for dinner and exploring their other dishes and brunch.
author: Andrew D.

description: Came here for dinner the other night with 4 other friends. Most of the dishes range around $13-16 and there are several delicious of vegetarian options. DO get the Monkey Bread to share, it's a great savory starter, and who doesn't loves carbs?! I'm typically not one to order a chicken parmesan sandwich, but the one at Corridor is outstanding, I highly recommend it if you're in the mood for a sandwich. The bread stayed crispy and the chicken was thick and tender. We also got the pesto & polenta ravioli which I thought had excellent flavor; the creamy kale sauce was pretty unique. It was an excellent dinner without doing a ton of damage on my wallet.
author: Cindy A.

description:
Good location to access many venues in the Civic Center area.
Space is a bit tight with limited tables both upstairs and downstairs. My group got a table for 4 in the back of the upstairs section. It was really loud and hard to hear one another.

Because we were a bit tucked away, I think it was hard for our waitress to see us. I had to flag her down several times to ask for water and then to get the check. We had also told her that we were trying to make a show; this usually triggers a server to optimize for time. Not so here. We were hoping to get dessert, and we had enough time to do so had she put in an order promptly. 

Service aside, the food was good. 
Truffle fries - perfectly crisped and well salted
Ravioli - delicious and delicate
Lasagna - a bit too cheesy for me and had an interesting steady burn from some kind of spice
Bolognese - decently meaty but also a little spicy undertones
author: Tina W.

description: Good monkey bread and soft scrambled eggs notwithstanding, our experience wasn't great. Absolutely no substitutions nor alterations to the set plates were allowed. For example, you can't get eggs on the side with corned beef hash. The enormous pancake was heavy. No sides of fruit available. The frittata seemed like it was made yesterday. The vegetables with the soft scrambled eggs were sprinkled on like an afterthought. Our server was a nice person, though.
author: Babette G.

description:
Went here yesterday for dinner with a friend both of us ordered the half roasted chicken.

The order was delayed, so chef brought us complimentary appetizers:
- monkey bread with Parmesan cheese
- meatballs with burrata cheese

I am both lactose intolerant and avoid gluten. Same as my dinner date. We looked at each and continued our wait for the chicken. 

I did manage to try the meatballs - they were excellent! I avoided cheese that was on the bottom of the plate. If I am back, I would recommend this dish for the table. 

The chicken arrived and looked extremely good; I got extra broccolini instead of mashed potatoes. My dish was juicy and flavorful. I just love chicken! 

We stayed a bit longer for the conversation and left shortly after. Service had a bit of a snafu when they lost or forgot to bring back my to-go box with the other parts of the chicken.

For $25 pop I think this restaurant provides a lot of value and serves tasty food. 

I disliked the noise level. All the sounds from the ground floor echoes throughout, and it was hard to hear my friend talking.
author: Anelya S.

description:
Came here for the Pre-Fixe menu on New Years Eve, and had a really mixed experience. A hard 'three-star' to land on, honestly, because some elements were truly exceptional. The location is absolutely perfect if you're going to the New Conservatory Theater for a show. The servers were all friendly. I loved the aesthetic, the vibe, the atmosphere. All of that was just spot on.

The food was just so... safe. Every course was fine, I mean nothing was bad. But nothing impressed either. The plating, even, was outstanding and everything looked fantastic. Like something out of a culinary magazine. And again, none of the food was sub-par... it's just that... you know that feeling when you take a bite of something and you non-verbally communicate to your dining companions how good it is? Then you talk about it later to people, encourage people to go and try it out, hurry back when you have the opportunity? That wasn't happening. I actually don't think I'd return... and yet... again... nothing was bad. Everything was just a little mild, and conventional, and safe. In a city full of exciting food, Corridor was just... the place you take your Midwestern relatives who are afraid of spice and bold flavors.
author: Sean B.

description: Had dinner here last night. Food was decent but way overpriced and very small portions. Know that if you don't have a reservation, all seating is communal so expect to sit with people not in your party.
author: Winston C.

description: Came here specifically for the monkey bread-- and it did NOT disappoint. Also ordered the spicy meatballs (sauce was great, the meatballs itself didn't have a ton of flavor). For entrees, we had the meatloaf wellington and duck confit.. both were just okay in my opinion. Loved the ambiance and decor, super modern and chic. Could be convinced to come back, mainly for the monkey bread :)
author: Kim I.

description:
Overpriced for portion sizes. No good plant-based options, so you're forced to order something with dairy and ask to hold the dairy (and they don't suggest an alternative). When I have tried to ask if I can assemble a simple plant-based plate (i.e. 3 small sides) they have not been accommodating. Sides are also not listed on the menu although I have found that it's possible if you ask. 

Upsides: Great coffee bar in the mornings, great space, friendly service.
author: Ashley M.

description: Great space and nice service. Highly recommend yellow corn risotto. It tastes so good.
author: Ryan T.

description:
My wife's best friend gave us a gift card so we decided to give it a try. The onion soup was definitely the highlight of the night!

We first ordered 1 onion soup, it was way too good so we ordered another one. We also ordered fried calamari, shrimp roll, and ravioli. 

I would highly suggest the onion soup and ravioli, the rest was good but didn't stand out as much either.

We came there at 5pm and didn't make a reservation. Luckily we didn't have to wait since it's still early. The staffs there were very friendly the entire time. And they checked our table very often.
author: Dino L.

description: Ok, this is definitely my FAVORITE place before SF Ballet. We come here often as we have San Francisco Ballet Season tickets so we enjoy dinner here before Ballet. Always so many people so we reserve well in advance. Right when we walk in, host offers us wine while we wait for our table. I love that attention. Everything they serve here is DELICIOUS and so far, excellent customer service. I mostly love their pastas & desserts so I highly recommend this awesome place. They also have good wine selection.
author: M A.

description: Food and drink was good but service was not great. Asked if the kitchen could whip up something vegan and was flat out told no whereas all other restaurants are always friendly and accommodating. Service was slow - my friend ordered a glass of wine and it hasn't come in fifteen mins so we had to cancel since we were catching a show. Really need to work on the hospitality aspect.
author: Michelle L.

description:
I'm glad there is a solid restaurant in that neighborhood as I often have meetings in the area. Surprisingly, Civic Center area lacks good options for sit-down lunch that are not loud lunch rush places. I love the atmosphere of a busy, dynamic city dinner, ramen joint, etc., but sometimes momma needs a quieter space and a glass of wine with lunch. 

The food is delicious, seasonal and fresh. Service is always on point. I personally like this style of service: more casual and warm but definitely still attentive and knowledgeable.

Atmosphere was open, modern, social and good acoustics for conversation. 

Good variety of options for most: salads, sandwiches, fish, meat, etc. Dishes are flavorful, generous portions and fresh ingredients. 

While I usually don't like such a heavy lunch, the pot pie is a winner, as well as the onion soup (which was more like a stew and very hearty).
author: April K.

description: Beautiful space -- even on a cloudy day this place get some nice natural light. Good option for meeting friends in the area. Dishes for lunch are on the pricey side.  Shrimp roll is delicious.
author: Heather R.

description:
A friend recommended this place when our original dinner plans fell through, and despite it being a super crowded/busy 80 degree day in SF, we were able to get a last minute table for 4 at 8pm on a Saturday. It's not a huge place, but it feels pretty spacious, and it's a little farther from the main craziness of Hayes Valley.

Beer and wine only.  We got some wines by the glass - the by the glass and bottle prices are pretty much the same. Prices aren't bad for SF at around $11-12/glass.

To start:
1. Green garlic soup: could have used a little black pepper, but it was a nice smooth green puree. It was a nice presentation - poured over asparagus, spring peas, pickled onions, poached salmon, garlic croutons  
2. Monkey bread: not as cheesy as I thought it would be.  It has cheddar in the middle, but the rest is like a lighter brioche-ish roll - very airy but also very oily. It's best eaten warm. 

Pastas:
1. Garganelli: with bolognese, burrata, and grilled sourdough. The bolognese had good flavor - nice and savory with a bit of spice from Calabrian chili. Pasta texture wasn't soft but wasn't al dente enough for me. the Burrata was the highlight of the dish.
2. Sweet corn risotto: with maitake Mushrooms and black truffle butter. I'm not sure the super sweet corn and truffle better were a perfect match, but the rice texture was ver proper, and I liked the giant parmesan shavings
3. Carbonara: the asparagus was a nice spin on the traditional carbonara. It wasn't overly heavy. Of the pastas, it was probably the one I liked best, but again, I think the pasta could have been more al dente

Main:
1. Crisp duck confit: good flavor and texture on the duck. It was a pretty big piece, served with forbidden black rice. I liked the Tokyo turnips and rhubarb in the black rice.

Portions were pretty substantial - we were all actually very full despite walking in starving. 

Food-wise, nothing was amazingly stand out, but they had a good variety on the menu.  Notably, the kitchen staff were great - the chefs were all super friendly and seemed happy to be there - from when we walked by the kitchen to head upstairs to when one of the chefs brought out a dish to when we departed the restaurant.
author: Marilyn T.

description: Good stuff. Good food, great service. The asparagus risotto is a MUST have....the location does not serve them well or would be hard to get in
author: Asif S.

description:
Nice restaurant under the 100 Van Ness residential complex. It serves mostly comfort food so don't expect anything too healthy here.  The food tastes good and I wouldn't mind eating here on any given night.  Corridor is a bit on the expensive side in my opinion, but I believe 100 Van Ness residents get a discount when opening a house account. 
My favorite thing here are the meatballs. They are drenched in a sweetish tomato pepper sauce and sprinkled with cheese and basil. There are little piece of pepper in the sauce which add a nice kick of spice. 
My boyfriend is a huge proponent of the bolognese here. I haven't had it myself but that's what he orders over and over. 
I've noticed that the monkey bread is one of the highlights here but I really have to say that I don't like it at all. It's super greasy and comes with a greasy dip. It's like eating garlic bread that has been soaked through with oil. It feels like a heart attack and I couldn't finish more than one piece before I threw the rest away. 
Overall, a solid dinner choice with the added benefit of being right under a residential complex.   The food is yummy but I would not recommend the monkey bread.
author: Amy X.

description:
This place was a great find. The perfect combination of really good food, great service and a great atmosphere.

We are upstairs which was a smaller area (maybe 12 tables) and they had a counter that overlooked the city.

We started with calamari which was delicious. It was perfectly fried, and a spicy aioli sauce, but also had potatoes and an olive tapenade mixed in. I was a little hesitant about that mix but it turned out to be great. 

For dinner we both had the Maine style shrimp roll. The brioche bun was small but flavorful and a good amount of shrimp. I was very pleased with the sandwich.

I got broccolini for a side - quite good. 

The waiter was very attentive, if any server walked by and your water was low they would fill you up. 

Really great place and we would definitely go back.
author: Trish B.

description:
Came to this place after passing by many times and figured it was a good opportunity to come after a show at the SF Symphony. Seems like an interesting place that had a very open design yet very modern. Situated on the bottom floor of the building it seems like a very welcoming place. Came here during their Happy Hour and they were offering beer, wine, and mocktails for $5. Started off food with their Grüner wine and some appetizers before the main course. 

Tthoughts on the Grüner wine. Never that type of wine, so it was enlightening to be able to try it. Being a White Wine, it's flavor profile seems to be quite positive. Not as sweet as a Sav Blanc and a lot drier. Good for people who enjoy that type of thing, and recommend trying out once. 

The Monkey Bread. A pretty decadent of fluffy bread topped off with some baked cheese on the top with a light layer of basil aioli. 

The spicy meatballs were not as spicy as most people think. I would think the Tomato probably offset it, but it had a nice sweet sauce that would compliment the meatballs well. The croutons were crunchy soaked well in the tomato sauce.

Panning the horizon for the flatbread, it ended up tasting alright with the different dips. Felt the flatbread wasn't too tasty and the sauces were decent but not as impressive as I would have thought.

Now to the entree. I ended up getting the Pan Roasted Salmon in medium rare compliment with cauliflower, Brussels sprouts, and walnut pesto. Thought that the charring on the vegetables gave an excellent effect that would compliment the salmon well. Salmon was very flavorful and did not seem overcooked. Bringing it together was the Walnut Pesto which provided a bit of a nutty yet a bit of an earthy sauce to the food.

Overall I think it's a good place to grab a decent meal which may be a little pricey. However, their happy hour provides a good value for beer and wine.
author: Frank O.

description: BUTTER FRIED PANCAKE w bananas, walnuts and stuffed with Nutella.  Amazing!  The coffee was good and the service was great.
author: Amanda R.

description:
A great dining experience. Note that it's of the same owners as Trestle and Stones Throw. Both I'd dined at in the last year or two. The restaurant is very efficient, and I love it for it. You order at the front counter. Names the dishes, and you can then head to a table to eat. They will bring the dishes to you as soon as you place the order. Or you can sit at the bar and order at the bar. We took the last table downstairs. Now that we are officially middle aged people, we started to share entrees and appetizers as opposed to ordering two large entrees. Old people like us can't handle heavy meals. The burrata and heirloom tomatoes (I know it's very basic and every semi decent SF new American restaurant has it now) and calamari mistro (not basic, and taste more like salad) came very quickly, and were delicious to boot. as much as I wanted monkey bread, I said no to the extra carb. He wanted the salmon and who am I to say no to the healthy choice? Medium rare was not cooked to medium rare, it's more of a medium but it's actually quite lovely. Chased it down with Belgium ale. 

All in all, a very efficient restaurant. Perfect location for opera, symphony or lectured goers. The restaurant can also be a good date place, though it's not terribly romantic for the set up, which I believe is its exact intent. I think the world has enough of those places, and its sister restaurants: Stones Throw on Hyde and Trestle on Jackson got those audiences covered. 

Note this is a fairly new restaurant in Civic Center area. It's price point is beyond reasonable for this city where a table for two religiously costs over $100. Here, the cost of two appetizers, both substantial and filling, and an entree, plus a beer on tap is way below it's contemporaries, and it all arrived within 10 minutes. Perfect for middle age people like I, who have places to go and bed to sleep in.  So is it because it's new that it's therefore charging less so to attract new patrons? Or is it designed to be on the more affordable side? I guess time will tell and I'm in no hurry to make this a known place to others.

Here I am, already kick started yet another season of City Arts and Lectures (have ticket on hand for the very first front row seat for Ira Glass and Bruce Springsteen but I shall not brag any further) and until I find something else as convenient as this, I imagine I will be back in a heart beat.
author: Victoria E.

description:
I'm typically wary of new eateries around the Van Ness Corridor. Given the gentrification that accelerated in the past 5 years (see 100 Van Ness Condos, The Civic, NEMA), I automatically assume that new restaurants would cost an arm and leg (just for appetizers!). 

Therefore I was surprised, and pleased, to learn that Corridor's prices were relatively decent! My girlfriend and I shared the french onion soup with braised beef short rib, spicy meatballs, English pea risotto; she also enjoyed a glass of wine while I had herbal tea. The total was about $60 - not necessarily as cheap as a hole-in-the-wall Tenderloin joint but it was certainly cheaper than Alta!

Note: Corridor is situated right on the intersection of Van Ness and Fell, surrounded by several theaters and the San Francisco Jazz Center. Perfect for date night!
author: John L.

description: Fast and kind service for the lunch rush. Friends thought the bun for the burger was dry, and the kale salad was VERY lightly dressed, but salad was still yummy. Half portion of salad (with half soup) still very filling with the almonds, chicken, and bacon. spring matzo ball soup al little salty, but loved the asparagus and peas in it. Everyone who ordered the pasta with buratta and basil loved it. Nice space upstairs for groups.
author: j w.

description:
There's something about the design and ambiance of this restaurant that makes it feel unique. It's a bit modern, and the layout is split into an upstairs and downstairs eating area. Even though there is plenty of space in both, the restaurant is usually busy and full, which speaks to how popular it can be. 

Food:
Monkey Bread - Lots of Yelp reviews raved about it, so I had to give it a try. Overall, it was pretty good, but maybe I had high expectations about it. It's worth a try and definitely tasty, but just not as good as it could be. A bit too oily/greasy.

Warm Flatbread & Dip Trio - Out of the three dips, the burrata and chermoula was the best. Salmon was interesting, but the texture and consistency seemed a bit odd. You can ask for more flatbread if you run out! Decent overall, but nothing amazing.

Pan-roasted Salmon - The sauce is divine. Really, that caper vinaigrette is quite something. It goes well with the salmon, brussels sprouts, cauliflower, and...surprisingly, the grapes. The salmon is roasted to have a crispy texture on the outside, and is perfectly soft on the inside. Apparently it's medium-rare, but it seemed like normal roasted salmon to me. My only issue is that there was way too much salt on the salmon.

Steak Frites - One of the specials during the evening when I went. The steak is decent and flavorful, but both the fries and steak were way too salty. About 6oz of meat, I believe. 

The food was good, but nothing really screamed "amazing" out of the dishes I tried. Corridor is worth a try, and seems to have a lot of potential. Sit downstairs to see the cool pull-out menus!
author: Chris D.

description:
Just came from dinner here on a Saturday night - I think the biggest surprise and disappointment was the general ambience and location of the space. To be honest, not knowing what to expect (just read that it was on the top 100), it felt like an upscale cafeteria/diner. I think it has to do with the concrete floors, and the communal tables were "sterile" with 6 tops that were set-up in a cafeteria style layout. We sat upstairs which was nicer but still lacked ambience.

I'm a big fan of casual, clean, simple, healthy cuisine. Reading the reviews gave me the impression that's what this was - but there were no salads or vegetable options on the menu. Everything was very meat or carb oriented - so if you are into that - this is your spot. I did order the burger (no bun) and asked for a green salad on the side, which they were happy to accommodate. My husband ordered the beef wellington which he said tasted good. Our friends ordered the special beef shortrib onion soup, which he said tasted good but surprised that it wasn't hot just warm. We also ordered the Monkey bread recalling a version that we had in Hawaii. This really was not the traditional "pull apart" monkey bread - it was tasty but I felt it was very rich and soaked with oil and didn't taste much of the cheese.

Overall, it was good - but did it stand out and inspire us to come back? Unfortunately not... I just had dinner at Alta which is also in the same neighborhood. I felt that the food was much better, more memorable, better priced, and a nicer ambience.
author: SY K.

description: This is a hidden gem in the middle of civic center. We walked in not knowing what to expect. The host and the waiters were extremely welcoming and helpful with menu selections and specials. The chef came over to our table to personally chat with us and find out what we liked. The presentation of each plate was right out of a gourmet magazine, and the food was absolutely to die for. I especially recommend the asparagus and mushroom risotto. Great wine selection as well. You won't be disappointed!
author: Pilar B.

description:
We (2 of us) arrived at 6:15pm on a Saturday.  Upstairs was full and downstairs was first come first serve.  We got 2 seats at the bar.  

Service:
Very quick.  The 2 waitstaff who helped us were very friendly.  

Food:
Monkey Bread
Mussels & Clams
Calamari 

Monkey Bread: We ordered based on the reviews we read.  The first piece was okay.  But after having some of a second piece, it got way too oily and fatty to finish anymore.  
Mussels & Clams: We experienced the same thing-way too fatty.  Every bite tasted of oil.  The sauce at the bottom had a nice lemon flavor.  But we couldn't finish it due to how fatty it was.
Calamari: This dish came out last and by then, fried food wasn't appetizing.

Overall: We were disappointed in the food.  It was so fatty and oily.  None of the food sat well.
author: Cindy M.

description:
the Corrido! of dindinsperado!
f double o d s check the flo
if you enter the do' then you dance the waltzo

3 cooks under pressured bakin that you get monkey bread

and eat more food than yo crew cause you amateur

what this how we eat it in the two o one six

it's time to go to meal photog drink eat what
author: Dan B.

description:
Really, really, wanted to like this place after reading the reviews and the close proximity to my weekend concert. Arrived hungry after a 6pm res and was seated immediately. That's where things took a turn. Waited 15 mins. for a sever to take a drink order (not busy) and another 10 for my dinner order. Decided to go with a hamburger/fries only because I was super hungry hoping that would be quick. Ordered it medium rare. Finally, (again not busy; 6:30pm on a Sunday) received a wafer-thin burger well-done and had to send it back. Quickly gott a better buger (thicker and more rare) and all would be fine except the fries tasted like someone had poured a shaker of salt on them, I kid you not. I kept trying to eat a few because I love fries and maybe they would be a little less salty at the bottom ??? No such thing. Thanks for trying to give me a complimentary little glass of Muscato, but needing to drive home after 3 (small pour) glasses of Pinot, it was not safe. I would have preferred comping one of my glasses of already drunk wine.
Sorry, but after $63.00 and the above I won't be back...
author: Cynthia J.

description:
I was really undecided if I should have given 3 or 2 stars! 
I decided to give 2 stars because even if the environment, the location (quite close to where I live) and the service was ok unfortunately the food wasn't that good! 
I took roasted chicken that I found tasteless (I never had a roasted chicken without salt and with vinegar on it) and cold! 
My husband's Meatloaf Wellington wasn't that bad but I don't think we will go back there!
author: Serena C.

description:
We had a reservation for a Friday night, so we forwent the counter experience and sat upstairs.  The ambiance was nice, not too loud as the space up there is pretty intimate (maybe 15 people or so).  The service was friendly and unimposing.  The food was amazing--with some of the signature dishes from Trestle and Stone's Throw, as many have mentioned, you can't go wrong.  We ordered too much and had plenty of leftovers.  I have a weakness for carbs, and tend to fill up on bread so I was hesitant with the Monkey Bread, but I'm so glad we went for it.  It's not nearly as dense as I thought it would be.  The pasta (a Trestle dish) was perfect and the meatloaf was juicy and a filling twist on the comfort food. 

I haven't been for happy hour but their prices look very reasonable.  I thought the prices for dinner weren't half bad either.  I will be back for sure!

To start:
-Falafel Croquettes
-Monkey Bread

Mains:
-Meatloaf Wellington
-Garganelli Bolognese

Imbibe:
-Sangria (2)
-Pinot Noir (2)

Tab (+tip): ~$145.00
author: Olivia D.

description: Holy! I wonder if they named this place for the wind. We stopped in here serendipitous-ly. We had originally planned to go somewhere else, but the line was crazy long so we skipped it since we were on our way to catch a show at the Orpheum (which is fairly close). There are two floors, didn't check upstairs, but a fair amount of seating in the main floor. A bar area some community tables. We sat at the community table next to another friendly couple. The stools were pretty tall and me being tiny, it was difficult for me to get my seat in. The guy next to me helped me into my seat. We ordered two drinks, and now I can't remember the names, but they were delicious. I had the sweet corn risotto. I love corn and I love risotto, so couldn't really go wrong. It was delicious and perfectly cooked. Not too mushy. Service was pretty good, fairly quick since we were in a rush. A little pricey, but I guess it is SF. Not horrible, but nothing I would make my way back here for. A-OK indeed.
author: Anjelica C.

description:
Came here before the Hamilton concert for dinner. I believe downstairs is walk in only and upstairs is for reservations. It's a bit small, but still comfortable. The food is simple, but delicious. Our service was excellent. I don't remember the name of our waitress, but she was amazing. We haven't had good service like that in awhile. We tipped her 25 percent.....

MONKEY BREAD-part Bread with Cheddar Cheese, Chive Oil, Basil Aioli-must get! Who doesn't like cheese bread. 

SPICY MEATBALLS-Tomato-Braised, Parmesan, Focaccia Croutons, Rosemary-super tender and flavorful. Not that spicy at all. 

GARGANELLI BOLOGNESE-Burratta, Basil, Calabrian Chili-cooked perfectly and the meat sauce was on point.

MEATLOAF WELLINGTON -Creamed Spinach, Orach Salad, Bordelaise Vinaigrette-not dry at all. Cooked perfectly, seasoned well and flaky pastry on the outside. 

This isn't on the menu, but they have a beef short rib french onion soup-a little heavy for me, but the hubby loved it

From the pics and reviews I got the ravioli with crispy kale. It was bland. So disappointed in this. Glad everything else was good though. 
 
'NILLA PUDDING TART-hubby liked this. I was too full to even take a bite.
author: Karen H.

description: This restaurant is pretty delicious! It has a nice upscale-ish/modern feel, which I really enjoyed. I came here with a group of 6 friends (side note: seating is limited so get a reservation!). I had heard about the "shareables" on the menu and wanted to try them out, as well as the French onion soup. We asked the woman we were ordering from for recommendations and she said the monkey bread, meatballs and falafels are the most popular sharbales. We took her up on her recommendation. My one complaint is that the portions don't seem QUITE big enough to be shared by a large group if you're all hungry, so I definitely needed the additional filling French onion soup. The monkey bread was BOMB!! Get it! It a great mix of rich flavors including garlic and pesto. Meat balls additionally were delicious and savory! The falafels were good as well, I'm just not a huge fan of those in general though. The French onion soup was also, unsurprisingly, delicious. I also got a great ginger drink for happy hour (I think it was a Top Hat? But I can't remember for sure). All in all, great experience and I'd happily come back again!
author: Courtney G.

description:
tl,dr: cold and bland food, inattentive service.

Having enjoyed dining at their sister restaurants Trestle and Stones Throw countless times, Corridor was an unfortunate disappointment. We live in the neighborhood and were originally pumped; hopefully everything we experienced was just symptoms of new restaurant growing pains.

From the start, things felt disorganized - the locked front door directed folks to walk around the restaurant, enter through the small side entrance, at which point we were ushered through the busy restaurant all the way back to...the front entrance? Why not just let us in there?

The concept is an upscale casual in that you order at the front at a register to be given a number, which you take with you to find open seating somewhere (note: this will probably be difficult for any party bigger than 4, as the tables are either communal or small)

FOOD: 
Monkey Bread: Like cheesy bread from dominos, just less cheese and more chives. 3/5

Ribeye: This literally came out cold. Not like "oh perhaps the server didn't pick it up quickly enough", but like, somehow-below-room-temperature cold. 1/5

Squid Ink Pasta: Pretty bland to be honest, it just wasn't remarkable in any way. 3/5

SERVICE:
I think due to the "order at front and find your own table" concept, servers aren't really assigned to particular tables. They were certainly friendly, but just very inattentive - we were only asked how things were going when dishes were being served/taken away. Felt like a cafeteria in that regard. 2/5

OVERALL: 2/5. Serviceable enough if this were any standard restaurant, but for a group that has such other fine establishments, we expected better. We had high hopes, and were severely disappointed.
author: Cody F.

description:
Casual dining with upscale food and warm, friendly, attentive service. Just the experience I was expecting from Chef Jason Halverson, Tai Ricci and Ryan Cole. 

We ate at Corridor with 4 guests and ordered quite a few dishes. I love the pastas from Trestle and Stones Throw and was looking forward to see how they translated to the new concept. They did not disappoint.

1 of our 4 guests was over 15 minutes late and they offered us a beverage immediately while we waited at the bar. We chose an affordably priced rose which was delicious. We ordered from the counter and were seated promptly.

We wanted lots of dishes to share, so we ordered:

CRISPY FALAFEL CROQUETTES - so light and crispy! Good sized portion and the best restaurant falafel that I have ever had.

FLATBREAD TRIO - loved the combination of choices, the spicy salmon spread was to die for and had to fight my table over every bite.

SPICY MEATBALLS - the sauce was so flavorful and not too spicy (the spicier the better for me but not for all of our group). Plus, the portion was a nice size we almost had 2 pieces each. Quite filling.

TOMATO & BURRATTA SALAD - the burratta was creamy and soft (not too chewy) and  the pesto gave it a brightness and depth of flavor with a hint of nuttiness.

ASPARAGUS RISOTTO - this was a table favorite, hands down. We could have eaten another and it was not a small plate. The rice was perfectly cooked and the texture was superb.

SQUID INK CONCHIGLIE - the classic from Stones Throw. Several of us have tried it many many times but one person just had to have it again and the squid ink pasta was so tender and the seafood plentiful. 

GARGANELLI BOLOGNESE - I think that this is from the Trestle menu and it was delicious. Not heavy, but very flavorful. Like what my Grandmother would make but better.

VEGETABLE POT PIE - this dish was surprising. It was very reminiscent of a certain Lobster pot pie with veggies. The crust was perfection.

STONES THROW'S DA BURGA - this was meaty and perfectly cooked. The slaw added the right crunch.

FRENCH FRIES - I love french fries and am a pretty picky when it comes to them. Not too thick, not too thin. Right on. Yumm.

CHOCOLATE WALNUT BROWNIE SUNDAE - we couldn't resist despite being so full. The hot fudge/whipped cream combination was the perfect end to a delicious meal.

I know that they had just opened, but our experience was great. Cost-wise, it didn't break the bank. The level of service was way above other casual concept that any of us had eaten at and the food was excellent.

I plan on making this a once a week stop as it is very accessible.
author: melissa l.

description: Came here for a date night and was really impressed. The food was delicious and the staff was great. We ordered the monkey bread, chicken entree and burger. I highly recommend this place!
author: Louise X.

description: Weird vibe, set up and seating process, but great food (pasta and monkey bread) and service.
author: Vicki L.

description:
the service was great from "go" and the food didn't disappoint. the portions are huge though so if you aren't really hungry, you might want to rethink adding monkey bread to your experience. saying that, the monkey bread was amazing!

wine selection is better than their beer selection but i wasn't disappointed in my choice of IPA.

i'd definitely come here again.
author: Tera K.

description: Cannot find anything positive about this place. Appetizer was overly salty mixing of hummus, tomatoes and small cold mussels. Quite a strange way to cook mussels. Pasta was soaked in oil and cheese. I only had 3 bites and couldn't continue to eat. Salmon was ok but the portion is so smaller , half of the usual size served in restaurant. Will Never go back.
author: Blue B.

description: My boyfriend and I walked over here last night for dinner with a friend from out of town. We really enjoyed the ambiance and the food. I ordered the vegetarian pot pie (highlyyyyy recommend!!), my boyfriend had the flank steak which he said was good for the price ($24) and our friend had the salmon which he said was prepared perfectly. Our waiter was wonderful, attentive, and knowledgeable. I wish I had gotten his name to give him a shout out! I really enjoyed the architecture of the restaurant and we had a nice view out the upper level windows. I'm sure we'll be back since we live so close! I do wish they had more wine by the glass options considering they do not have a full bar with hard alcohols.
author: Kim A.

description: Perfect for a nice but quick dinner before a show. Great service and prices. You walk in and order at the front but from then on out it's like eating at any other nice restaurant - food, ambience, wine list. We loved it.
author: Joycerine L.

description:
I am so jealous of the people that live above Corridor. If I lived there, I would eat there everyday. I would make myself a special tunnel so I could go back and forth with ease.
Their menu is a little difficult because simply you want to order everything. We settled on monkey bread, shrimp rolls , vegetable pot pie and tomato and burrata salad. The monkey bread reminded me of the cheesy bread you get from Sizzler's but a 100 times better. The shrimp rolls were light and flavorful on a perfectly toasted buttery roll. You would never miss the meat in the vegetable pot pie. Pure decadence! This is a perfect place to have a fine dining experience in a casual setting.
author: Sophia C.

description:
Monkey bread!! Shockingly no one else in my group knew what it even was. I still remember making this in home ec using those biscuits in a can. Of course this stuff is much better. Buttery light brioche type bread with yummy cheesy goodness.

Only came here for happy hour so can't really say much except the monkey bread was excellent and they had a pretty good drink selection. The drinks were a bit on the pricey side so be sure to get here before happy hour ends at 6pm.

Oh yeah, it's super loud inside.
author: Jean K.

description:
There is a lot of freeking street noice and construction around here

They leave the front door open so the dust and noise creep on you

The space is colored dull and muted, like a dentist office. I am sure positive that it was a foyer at birth

Don't buy the monkey bread, this is a hunger killer.

The waitrons are so efficient you swear they are robots.

Smoke the Trout.
author: Willi P.

description: Came here because of the review and I am incredibly disappointed. The food is very, very... bland. We didn't even get the proper condiments for our oysters. Only come here if you want to get disappointed :(
author: Vien C.

description:
Sarah was the star of our dinner last night.  The food was also outstanding especially the new on the menu sweet corn - curry soup!!  Best falafel ever and the 3 pea salad most inventive and tasty salad ever!  Salmon was cooked to perfection while my duck was good however the skin should have been crispy(er).  
Service and food outstanding plus a good value for this neighborhood.
Definitely will be back for dinner before our next Symphony date.
author: Marty D.

description:
Maybe I hit it on an off night, but I really did not enjoy the food at this place. 

I also think there's a strange service experience when you first arrive if you're seated upstairs. The hostess gives you a coin and just tells you to walk up the steps and give it to a server. I was confused and ask what is this for she said it's your table assignment. OK, then why didn't she just explain that to begin with. I can see that going up and down the stairs all night might be problematic, but I've been to other restaurants with different levels that don't have this process.

We ordered the monkey bread, which was nothing special. The meatloaf Wellington comes with two sides of different spinach preparations, which I find strange. The Wellington had a strong sharp taste that I did not enjoy. I also tested the salmon and it had absolutely no flavor.

I was looking forward to trying this place, but I will not be recommending it to anyone I know.
author: Sharon G.

description:
Nice ambiance and a good menu selection make this a really good choice if you're in the Civic Center area.

Get a reservation and they'll escort you upstairs - above the noisy bar scene where it seems like you can get the same menu.  Otherwise, you're downstairs with order-at-the-counter and a loud cafeteria-style ambiance.

Tried a number of things including:
- Top Hat - non-alcoholic "moscow mule" which was really fresh and delicious
- Flatbread Trio - thought these would be baked, but they were just basically pita with 3 spreads.  Salmon was good, but spicy.  Avocado was weird.  I almost never met an avocado I didn't like, but this was one...  Burrata was luscious.
- Trout and Farro salad - really good... could have used some more trout and a bit of salt.  Lots of potatoes.
- Salmon - really delicious (heard from across the table)
- Vegetable Pot Pie - light pastry and good broth, but lots of potatoes.  Would have loved more mushrooms, carrots...  left about 1/2 cup of potatoes on the plate.
- Corn on the Cob - Really, really good.

Overall, service was attentive and friendly, small space, but felt open and airy and food was generally good.  Would like it even more if there were some less carb-heavy options, but probably will be back.
author: Bob K.

description:
Was looking for a place to have a company dinner for 8 and a friend recommended this spot. The upstairs was booked but they offered the high top tables on the entrance floor. Our reservation increased to 10 so they were able to move us upstairs.

We ordered a bunch of dishes to share. Staff here is top notch. Only downside was the space is a little loud for a large group. Calamari and meatballs were highlights!
author: Tiffany Y.

description:
3 stars: 4 for location if you are going to the symphony or ballet or anything in the immediate vicinity. 2.5 stars for food.

I was a little confused by the food here because I loved everything I've had at Stone's Throw, and I believe this is owned by the same people. Granted I haven't been to Stone's Throw in a couple years, but the level of food here is totally different.

We got:
- spicy meatballs - good, but nothing special
- French onion soup - good, but also nothing special 
- butternut squash & leek risotto - the best thing we got. Every bite was deliciously savory, perfectly rich and just the right amount of truffle.
- shrimp roll - very disappointing. Both the sandwich and the shrimp inside are tiny and very mayonnaisey. 
- meatloaf Wellington - the item I was most excited for but sadly fell flat. Would have been better just as a slab of meatloaf as the pastry did almost nothing for this dish.

Overall I would say that this is an ok option if you have plans nearby for the evening and need to make a reservation, but sadly I wouldn't recommend coming here for the food.
author: Amy Y.

description: This place was great!  Definitely get a reservation so you can eat upstairs.  Order the monkey bread and the French onion soup!
author: Christopher F.

description:
This place is just so confusing, it gave me whiplash trying to figure it out. We had a reservation but we're running late. When I called in, they were amazingly helpful and kind in the phone. But from the moment we arrived, service was overly fussy and fiddly for a casual joint. It became a joke how many times the waitress would refold our napkins before the entrees came. 

Monkey bread was unique and interesting. However,  our three entrees were not very exciting. The meatloaf was fine but it was served with a salad and "bread dust". While they were trying to be fancy, it was unappetizingly close to dirt in your salad. The burger was fine. The carbonara was drowning in sauce that wasn't seasoned and didn't have enough bacon to fix it. The blackberry sundae was quite good. However, the 'nilla pudding tart was all banana, with no indication that it would be. 
Overall, it was fine but nothing to go back to.
author: Tracy C.

description:
Solid place for a good meal and drinks. More a 3.5* but the burger pushes it up.

I had the burger which was great! Nice thick patty, perfectly cooked and you could tell the quality. Cheese was perfectly melted on top and the fries are great too.

The lady had he Ravioli which she though was good but nothing phenomenal.

Go with the burger - that's what would bring me back.
author: Farid V.

description:
Casual atmosphere with lots of ambiance options.

You can either sit downstairs for a pub feel or make a reservation upstairs for a more intimate setting. Decently priced but still good food with interesting flavors. Will definitely be coming back often.
author: Justin S.

description:
I went here last night for a double date.  Upon entry we were greeted by a very enthusiastic host who helped explain the menu and take our order.

Since this is a fast casual spot, we were quickly seated upstairs in the dining room.  Though pretty funny, right as I sat down- the chair legs broke from right under me.  There were obvious giggles all around, but not much worry from the staff that I could have been hurt.

Additionally, as if that wasn't bad luck enough-- my fork had left over fry food on it  (GROSS) and at the end of the meal during cleanup the waitress spilled more food on me.

The food was generally good, we enjoyed the play on the"monkey bread".  The other food all came out a little bit cold -- disappointing.

I've eaten A LOT of meals in San Francisco, and would expect with such shitty luck, at this type of restaurant that our check would get comp'd somewhat for the various mistakes made.  But no luck.

To the business owners- 
I hope you guys read this.  When your staff makes so many mistakes, general rule of thumb is to be nice and treat the customers in some sort of way.  Hoping they learn and to continue to make these.
author: ilya g.

description: Ugh.  Been here several times, every previous time I've had a very nice meal and good experience. But just recently-Wow!   My food option was unbelievably bad.  Ordered the  Cobb salad. My buddy ordered the falafel- neither of us were satisfied.  The avocado in my salad looked several days old.  The turkey--- looked gray....  Not nice.  I still think it's a cool venue, but they need to figure out the whole ordering thing.  Place is too pricey to be stand-and-order then sit-down-and-pay joint.  With so many options mid-market now, this place is off the list.
author: R G.

description: Got the breakfast sandwich which honestly wasn't great - was not a fan of the mushrooms and they should have included more egg. They also have a weird ordering system where you order at the counter but then pay at the table which just seems inefficient. One guy told me the fried chicken sandwich was the best thing on the menu so that's what I'm getting if I come back.
author: Kimaya C.

description: Food here is not bad. Got their famous monkey bread, sour beer, and burger. The monkey bread was ok and the burger was really good. Good service too. Beer was ok. I'd come back for the burger.
author: Lisa T.

description: Ambience is nice, staff was friendly, food "ok".  Daughter said "nothing special".  If we were in area again -may come back.....
author: Jennifer N.

description:
Cute place! Great food which you can expect from the same owners of trestle!

The upstairs is where you can sit down for a regular dinner, whereas downstairs is more for the bar / bar seating. I sat upstairs because we had a reservation. It's small and the tables are a bit tight but they're maximizing space up there. Definitely not for large groups.

The must have dishes: the monkey bread and the French onion soup. Everyone has mentioned the monkey bread because it is absolutely delicious and great to share for the table. The French onion soup was small but yummy. My only con was that it said there was supposed to be short rib in there and mine had no chunks of meat whatsoever. But I love the classic French onion soup which doesn't have meat anyway so it was still good.
author: Jennifer Y.

description: One of my fave newer eats in the Civic Center area! Convenient to the symphony and opera, open lively space. In July went with a few friends, pretty much everything was fantastic, with the notable exception of the desserts which were just average. Standouts included the: monkey bread (pull apart bread with cheddar cheese, olive oil), calamari misto (with smoked potato, harissa aioli, olive tapenade), sweet corn risotto (with truffle butter, roasted maitake mushroom, parmesan), tagliatelle carbonara (with asparagus, prosciutto, poached egg, parmesan cream), veggie pot pie (with corn, confit potato, pearl onion), crispy duck confit (with forbidden black rice, rhubarb, Peking style jus). As mentioned, the desserts were just so-so (crostata and the sundae), but the main dishes were so uniformly solid, this place still gets 5 stars from me plus a return visit in the near future!
author: Andrew L.

description: If you have never had the monkey bread at the Corridor Restaurant then you definitely need to head there just for that. I have been there several times and that has always been the highlight of my evening. I have never had anything like it before and found it to be quite exceptional and unique to this place. I keep returning simply for their monkey bread. The modern ambience of the restaurant is always a welcoming sight and most times I enjoy my time here. I have had other things on their menu as well and they were somewhat ok. The Corridor Restaurant I will recommend simply for their monkey bread. No monkeying around with that!
author: Federick H.

description: These guys were fast, accommodating our need for a quick turn around before a show. The food was fresh. clean flavors and lived up & beyond. 4 of us ordered all of the apps but 2 to share and that was enough for a full meal. our waiter was fantastic, fun and efficient without intruding.
author: Alanna M.

description: This is a great spot for a reasonably priced meal before a show. I recently had a confusion with a reservation and the staff were great about helping to figure things out. Yummy food friendly and relaxed service
author: Katy O.

description: The bartender and servers were excellent. Food was great too! Everything was really professional and exceeded my expectations.
author: Teresa W.

description:
Not only their waiter was rude but their manager decided we were not good enough to enjoy their restaurant.

Homophobic, obnoxious, and definitely unwelcoming
Enjoy a restaurant that Donald Trump would love
author: Francesc F.

description: No complaints! Ordered the half roasted chicken and it was really good. Also ordered the monkey bread which me and my girlfriend devoured! Totally recommend this place
author: Megan N.

description:
Let down unfortunately

We love stones throw so we were super excited to try corridor

We got 3 things recommended by other Yelpers

1) monkey bread --- good but too buttery and heavy. And too much salt

2) duck confit salad --- ok not great, way way too much salt

3) chicken parm sandwich -- good but too much salt (notice the trend?)

Perhaps it was an off night but everything was way too salty and we definitely don't have picky taste buds. It was fine but nothing special and considering $45 for the good above, a real let down.
author: Sai S.

description:
Nice spot that I checked out for dinner, although the happy hour seems like a great deal too.  The calamari was quite good and the falafel just ok. The pasta bolognese was tasty but also very rich. 

Definitely will try this place again.
author: Dave R.

description: My family and I came here for lunch before seeing the Nutcracker. The concept is a little odd. You come in and order your food and first round of drinks at the counter. This is similar to how they do things at pubs in London. You're given one of those little buzzy things for when your food is ready. If you don't have a reservation you just find a place to sit downstairs. I had made a reservation so we went upstairs where we had a table. When our food was ready they brought it to the table. And any subsequent drinks or dessert you can order from your waiter. I think they do a lot of sharing here because they have a tendency to cut things into portions. For example my daughter had the burger and even though we said not to cut it up they cut it into four pieces anyway. When her burger first showed up even though we had said only cheese and nothing else it's still had some sauce on the bottom so we had to send it back. Our food came out in waves. My wife's salad came first and then we waited quite a long time for the rest of our meal to show up. I guess this is part of their whole sharing concept but it was a little awkward while we waited and waited for the rest of the food. The food itself was very good. I had the salmon which was excellent. It came with some brussels sprouts and some grapes of all thing which was an excellent  accompaniment. My son had a roast chicken which was also excellent. And my daughter gave the burger five stars. The total for four of us plus tip was 170.
author: Scott S.

description: Chicken was half raw--specifically asked for it to be fully cooked. Service was also not very nice.
author: F H.

description:
My husband and I went to Corridor last night for date night. BIG MISTAKE. We shared the trio of dips, I got the ravioli and my husband got the burger. The food was average, and our order was an hour late. No biggie, though, and they comped the appetizer and drinks to make up for it. But then we got home, and boy, the night was just getting started. Two hours later, we both had stomach grumbles, nausea, gas, the works. 

Yup, we'd gotten food poisoning. Our one year old woke up to sounds of loud retching. Relentless vomiting and diarrhea later, we had to make a trip to the ER at 3 am. 15 hours later, things still aren't looking great, but at least I could write this review. 

The likely culprit is the burrata in the appetizer we shared. Not sure if this was a one-off, but consider yourself warned.
author: Riddhi S.

description:
Wow, wow, wow. A serious food-centric restaurant in an extravagantly casual setting. The food preparation and technique are serious fine dining. The service -- other than the order-at-the-counter affectation -- is better and more polished than more serious restaurants charging 2-3X the price. Get up? They fold your napkin. Run out of water? They fill it. Dirty your share plate? They bring a new one without asking. Knock some kibblets on the wooden table? They rush over with a cloth to wipe it off for you.

The food itself was somewhere between creative, delicious, and informing. When the food talks to you, that's good.

The night we came the restaurant group's head chef was there keeping order, and you could tell he is a serious chef. Everybody was afraid and respectful.
