He smiled at the customers and I imagine he was tearing organs out of cooks and murdering kittens in the prep room. There were some glitches to be sure, fish overdone, the counter person didn't properly explain or ring up the "two sides" theory, we had a few qualms about some of the recipe decisions, but that would be judging an everyday priced restaurant against the standards of special occasion places at 2-3X the price. In fact, I could make this a special occasion restaurant for me.
author: Gil S.

description:
A stone's throw from Hayes.
Lies a corridor to heaven...
Passage to my belly.
author: Nish N.

description: I have been to the Corridor Restaurant twice and I have to say that the happy hour always leaves me happy especially when I have the monkey bread. You can never go wrong with a little monkey bread in your life. I have only had it once but it has become a craving. I love the taste and texture of it and will definitely be coming back for more once I can. The ambiance of this place is really good and you can always expect a friendly, welcoming staff. I love it here, for the great prices, exceptional service and fascinating dishes that can satisfy any taste preference.
author: Penny L.

description:
Came here for quick grab and go during my lunch hour. A lot of times if i am unfamiliar with a new place i like to order a safe bet meal. That's exactly what i did at The Corridor. Ordered a simple grilled cheese that was simply amazing! 
It was one of those meals that made me reach for my phone and convince my bestfriend she needed to experience this grilled cheesiness.

I know what you might be thinking, "man this girl mustve been starving that day or is exaggerating over a freaking grilled cheese"

No my friend, no. Try it out for yourself. It will not disappoint.
author: Leli C.

description: Despite my strict AIP protocol, I melted as I read the menu: "Monkey Bread," stuffed with cheddar and parmesan cheeses, I mean the bread alone would've been enough, but oozing greasy melted cheese is downright diabolical. I relented and ordered it, it's a round lofty dish begging to be inhaled, which we did. If you don't like bread and don't go crazy for cheese, stay away from this, because it'll break your heart with goodness. We also got their winter root vegetable salad, roasted carrots, parsnips, radish coins, and more--lovely as the sophisticates say. Then came the flank steak, medium as we ordered--tender and juicy, easily cut with the serrated knife. Instead of cream spinach, we asked for simply wilted spinach without the cream, which they obliged. The service was fantastic, several people came to check on us, and when I realized that their sesame dressing on one of the salads was waaay too spicy and inedible for me, they gladly substituted it. Friendly, warm, cordial, they made us feel welcome. I loved the upstairs seating, away from the cacophony of the downstairs kitchen and bar area. It was relatively quiet, despite getting filled up fast on a weeknight. Terrific little place for unpretentious dining, solid ingredients and preparation, with excellent service. Without this AIP protocol, if I could eat anything I wanted, the menu has so much more I wish I could've ordered.
author: Ranjan P.

description:
I was really excited to eat here for lunch, as there are not many good restaurants around the Civic Center area - one would have to walk to Hayes Valley to get good food.  Anyway, I received an email from Yelp that this new restaurant opened in the area.

I decided to go to the Corridor restaurant rather than the Corridor café next door because I wanted a comfortable place to sit down to enjoy my lunch.  I ordered the French onion soup and the calamari appetizer.  The French onion soup was good, but I would have preferred that it stayed in the oven a bit longer to get the brown cheese crust on top (it was light brown and not crusty). Nevertheless, the soup was OK.

Now for the bad part - the calamari appetizer/salad.  The calamari was cut in tiny, tiny pieces.  They were so small that the chef should have known that it should only be deep-fried for a few seconds.  Instead, the calamari was overcooked and rubbery (ugh!) and the dressing on the dish was overwhelming (again, ugh!).

I had great expectations of this restaurant, but alas it was not to be!
I should note that the service staff was excellent and friendly.
author: Chilly W.

description: Deliciousness!!  Had the salmon which was perfectly cooked and enhanced by the chowder broth. And don't get me started on their monkey bread! I normally don't have dessert, but I'm so glad that I did! 'Nilla pudding tart!!! I will go back just for that decadently creamy, crispy, banana-ish concoction! And the service was impeccable as well as friendly! Perfect place to have a meal before a show (Tony Bennet in our case). Thank you Ryan for a wonderful experience!
author: Stephanie Y.

description: The Happy Hour is very good with a wide selection of wine by the glass to choose from ($5 a glass during HH), and they have a solid food menu that is available during HH and regularly to close time (no special pricing for the HH but decently priced regardless). Service was very friendly, flexible and accommodating. It's a nice location with lots of windows and natural lighting and plus very close to BART/Muni at Civic Center/Van Ness, plus near major Muni bus lines like 49/47 and 21.
author: Maile N.

description: Small and very industrial looking.  Uncomfortable chairs.  Noisy.  But it has the best egg sandwich i have ever had.  Tender egg, toasted croissant, creme fraiche.  Nicely seasoned and salted.  Perfection.  4 stars just for that.  Will go again just for the egg sandwich.
author: Brian G.

description:
We live in the building so we were really excited to try Corridor! Everyone was very friendly and the host at the front explained the process and how the ordering process works if you are eating downstairs (upstairs requires a reservation or only if there is available seating).

For those who live in the building they offer a discount, but for some reason they were not able to set up an account at the time. They offered no other solution to this and so we were not able to use this discount.

My husband ordered the risotto with black truffle butter - it was the most bland thing we had ever eaten. We think they forgot the truffle part of it because we didn't taste this at all. Very disappointing.

I had the vegetable pot pie and this was actually very good - def recommend!

The dessert was also disappointing, we had the brownie sundae and the brownie was very dry, not sweet and the entire dessert was nothing special.

We were expecting more, but also hoping that since they are new they are working to improve things. We'll probably give it one more try.
author: Monika V.

description:
We had enjoyed our dinner at Trestle so we decided to try dinner at Corridor. We had made a reservation so instead of ordering at the counter and finding a table we were escorted to the mezzanine and had full table service. The service was helpful and responsive, which started things off well. 

I started with a glass of rosé and a bowl of the corn chowder special. My wife had the Gone With The Wind sherry cocktail and the chicories salad with duck confit. I can vouch for her salad. It was tasty and enormous. it could be an entire meal or plenty to share.

I then had a glass of Chianti and the Garganelli pasta, plus an order of roasted carrots to share. I loved them all, but couldn't finish the pasta or the carrots. My wife had the corn chowder for her entreé and a glass of Chardonnay. 

The wines were all lovely, reasonably priced for the quality, and generous pours.  My wife loved her sherry cocktail. The entire meal was surprisingly inexpensive, but ordering a starter as a main course and a pasta as the other main undoubtedly helped.

We were too full to order dessert.

We had gone early so we'd have time for a relaxing meal before a show at SFJAZZ. Our waiter asked whether we had any time constraints and got us out in plenty of time.

We'll be back.
author: Robert W.

description: I have been to the Corridor Restaurant only once and it has a very modern, vibrant atmosphere. I was quite impressed by the space and the service was exceptional. We went there during their happy hour period and you definitely will not experience anything better. The service was on point, and you most certainly need to try some of the different things on their menu. I managed to have their meatballs and pot pie, and it is something to talk about. The pot pie was well done and the sauce that came with the meat balls added an extra touch of elegance and taste. Happy hour at the Corridor Restaurant was incomparable and we definitely were in great spirits after it. Recommended!
author: Alice Dee W.

description: A friend and I had dinner at Corridor last night and although I had been here before the service last night was exceptional. A huge shout out to the host who checked in with the kitchen to make sure we could be in and out before we had to leave for a show. As we were waiting for our table he came back regularly to us to give us updates on when our table would be ready. As we waited we observed his interactions with other guests and his service was above and beyond. Good service goes a very long way with me and of course the great service was matched with great food. I remember the food being fabulous from my last visit and it continues to be so. I cannot wait to go back!
author: Elzabeth G.

description:
We came before the symphony again this evening and the service was abysmal. 

We arrived at 6:00 for a 6:15 reservation and at 7:40 we were finally served our entrees, just in time for us to ask for to-go boxes and the check. Very, very disappointing.
author: Nick S.

description: The food was spectacular. I'm often pleased with the efforts put forth by today's dining experience, but every so often I find a course that is so well balanced and so intriguing that it sticks with me. I find myself thinking about it long after the plates have been cleared. The flatbread app with three dips was such a course.  Hummus, burrata and salmon all melded together to create a tastebud explosion of goodness. Well done.
author: Angela L.

description: What a GREAT FIND!  HOLY CRAP!  This place is amazing!  The quality of food you get for the price is INSANE!  You have to try the Calamari Misto, the Bolenese Pasta and the Flake steak!  My girlfriend and I loved every dish!  Definitely will be back!
author: Garren R.

description: I'm a fan of corridor for mid afternoon meals. They have a solid selection of wines and keep the menu pretty simple. The dishes actually leave you full which is a huge plus for moderate prices.
author: Kaego R.

description:
Looking for a fast, quality meal? This is the place. I've eaten here at lest once a week since they opened. The menu is diverse and everything's delicious. My favorites are the calamari misto for $11, pasta bolognese for $16, half roasted chicken with a side of potatoes and veggies for $19, a delicious chicken parmigiana sandwich with broccolini side for $14. It's easy to walk in and sit at the bar or a communal table. 

The food Is SF quality but the service is not SF. I mean that as a compliment. The staff are friendly, accommodating and treat you like a guest. Something you don't get in most SF restaurants where you're treated more like a nuisance. I don't know what their secret sauce is but it's working. I love this place!
author: R D.

description: Froendly staff, love the cafe atmosphere/seating (natural light),, and lastly, the food is amazing.  Shrimp roll tasty on very soft roll.  Bolognese is a popular dish. The fried chicken sandwich is classy. Fries are addicting with the aioli dip.
author: Ju D.

description:
I'm happy to have this place around the corner from my apartment, it's quality food without the painfulness of reservations, snootyness, and high prices that plague the neighborhood. I've had both the burger and the chicken parm sandwich. The chicken parm is actually too big in a good way and is packed with great flavor and without the sogginess that often plagues the genre. I have not eaten upstairs, but I'm sure it is the same great food but with full service.

I would love to see them do a late night menu and/or cheaper take out specials. Also what's with the beer prices? I'd happily come in for just drinks if they had some $6 options.
author: Kurt N.

description: Came here for happy hour with coworkers for my farewell. Super friendly staff and food is overall good (not the calamari tho). The only thing we noticed is that the wine pour is not at all consistent. We noticed certain group of customers get heavier pour.. I wonder why. Hopefully not because of their whiteness.
author: Doris H.

description: Simple review: good food, good service, good location when seeing a show. Reservation recommend at least a week in advance if you're seeing a show.
author: Ranee W.

description: Surprisingly delicious food. I wasn't sure what to expect because I'd never heard of Corridor, but their bolognese was amazing! The service was good, prices were fair and the ambiance was decent. I'd definitely go back.
author: Silva Y.

description: This place was just okay. We tried the fried calamari appetizer and their burger and both were fine but really nothing that made you say "this is good!" The upstairs eating area feel disconnected and strange- I didn't enjoy the atmosphere up there, maybe downstairs near the bar would've been better. I work near it so I tried it but I don't think anything would tempt me to go back. Unfortunate.
author: Piper W.

description: Literally across the street from my office, I am at Corridor on average twice per day! Sometimes 3 if I need that afternoon caffeine injection. Delicious pastries, excellent breakfast, superb lunch. I think I have tried nearly everything on the menu. My favorites at breakfast are the sausage burrito, croissant with bacon egg and cheese and the butter fried pancake. Lunch go ahead and belly up to the table with either the fried chicken sandwich, da burga or the garganelli bolognese...maybe the pasta is for dinner. Hmmm...I really go here way to much! Good food and awesome people...I can't resist.
author: Rommel T.

description: Dinner was not great. The bolognese sauce tastes like Chef Boyardee and the "duck confit" is a pile of red cabbage with a few chunks of duck breast. The beer options are excellent and they have rotating taps. I would give 3 stars, but it's expensive- $15-$20 for entrees that are worth closer to $10.
author: Chris B.

description:
Corridor is one very good restaurant.  FIrst off, it is located in the restaurant desert near the  civic center and is ensconced in a lovely, two story venue.  Lest I forget, service was very good.  Of course one would expect that from the newest member of the Stone's throw/Trestle restaurant group.  But it's really all about the food with me.  How they manage to keep pricing so low is incredible.  However, why complain about a bargain?  And the food itself is up-dated comfort food with a twist.  

For example short rib onion soup comes topped with a layer of cheese, naturally.   Underneath the cheese is a tasty melange of short rib, carrots and tomatoes.  Wonderful.

A salad of smoked trout, quinoa, green apples, potatoes, dill and horseradish is large enough to be a main course and every bite was tasty.

Finally, pedestrian meatloaf has been upgraded to meatloaf wellington.   The immense portion of meatloaf comes with crushed potatoes and a medley of vegetables.   

If you like really good food at bargain prices then Corridor is for you.
author: David D.

description:
This is a review of dinner. The chicken parm sandwich is the best chicken parm ever and I've lived in Philly! ;) Perfect bread. Perfect sauce. Gooey cheese. Tender meat. Also try the corn on the cob. 

Generally the portions were large. The gargnelli was overcooked and bland despite the fresh basil and chili oil. Needs some vivid flavors. The salmon entree was also boring and the fish was too salty. But I will definitely return for the chicken parm. Will bump up a star if I have any more "destination-worthy" dishes. 

No high hairs for kids. No kids activities. Elevator can take strollers up to upper level. Very nice wait staff.
author: Marina N.

description:
My favorite part was the dessert - nilla pudding. Sooo delicious! Vanilla pudding in a little crust with pieces of banana, whipped cream and some other magical ingredients. 

We had reservations before the opera...for some reason, and even though we had reservations, we were sat at a bench both facing out. Initially, it was also difficult getting our drink order and placing our second drink order. 

The mains and appetizer were decent but nothing to rave about (bolognese, risotto, monkey bread). The mains were very rich. The monkey bread was on the dry side.
author: Young B.

description:
A nice new restaurant, with a fairly simple menu and really tasty food.

We shared the monkey bread and meatballs apps, then both ordered entrees ... which was a little much, and ended up taking doggie bags home (which they label individually - nice touch!).  It seems like most of the food here is really rich, so we would cut back on ordering on our next visit.

The service is outstanding, throughout. Very friendly staff without being overbearing.

The setup is a little strange: downstairs, the bar atmosphere offers long banquet tables for sharing, accommodating probably 8-10 guests.  Upstairs, there are about 10 tables, which fill up quickly with the theater crowd.  The set up is a little awkward, with someone at your table having to face a blank wall with their back to the room. A bar top overlooks the downstairs entirely, so we'd request that seating next time.
author: Ron F.

description:
Came here around 8:00pm on a Saturday night, place was empty downstairs. Thought we'd try it out because of the good Yelp reviews. We didn't have a reservation so we ordered at the counter and then got a beeper thing. This was  a bit confusing because they also have servers and menus at the table but you pay back up at the counter before you leave. We wanted to order beer after we had sat down but it took forever to flag the waitress. Our food ended up coming out long before she came back with the beer.

I ordered the mushroom vegetable pot pie.  It had a delicious-looking crust on top of a cast iron skillet.  It looked promising but there was fairly dry filling and didn't have much inside of it. The pie was mostly filled with air. The pieces of mushroom and potato that were in there tasted good, but it wasn't as filling as I would've hoped. It came with a wedge salad on the side that looked good, but I personally wasn't a fan of the mustard dressing they put on it.

My boyfriend got the burger. Again, it looked promising, but was EXTREMELY buttery. The meat was cooked well. 

All-in-all, fun ambiance, weird service system, and good beer selection, but the food was absolutely not worth it for the price.
author: Rachael R.

description: I stop in here to grab coffee to go all the time and the coffee is great, but the service is even better! Every single staff member I've interacted with has been SO great. I tried the breakfast a few weeks ago and was not disappointed! The hash was delicious and the breakfast sandwich was a great size. Can't recommend this place enough!
author: Jordan A.

description: Easily one of my favorite places to eat in SF. I found the prices to be incredibly reasonable given the portions and food quality. I love the Rosé sangria, you call tell that they have infused this for at least a day, if not longer. Their menu rotates, but I always get the cheddar herb monkey bread. It's deliciously savory, but is lighter than most brioches! Last night I had the meatloaf Wellington, and a side of leek bread pudding. Both were fantastic, with good balance of flavors and textures- with a little bit of acidity to combat the richness. I can honestly say that each time I have been, they never disappoint!
author: Nathan K.

description: Their system here is really flawed. You have to stand in a line to order and then I waited for a really simple drink for 20 minutes. I haven't tried their food.
author: Kerri B.

description: I'm flattered by the amazing service and also blown away by the awesome grilled cheese and iced vanilla latte ! A somber ambience with friendly staff , and good location. I'd highly recommend this place
author: Shivam D.

description:
Being a big fan of both Stones Throw and Trestle, I was pretty excited to try Corridor last Friday night. Just like at the group's other restaurants, the staff was very nice and welcoming. We had a reservation and got a great seat on the second floor. We received really great recommendations from our waitress on how big the portion sizes were and what the appropriate amount of food would be for two people.

The highlights had to be the Monkey Bread and The Garganelli Bolognese, both were out of this world good. Definitely include them in your order!
author: Andrew K.

description:
I do wish Yelp allowed half stars. There is a range between decent and really good, between really good and superlative, that could only be expressed in half stars. Corridor is a 3 1/2 star.

Arrived on time for Happy Hour, when beer, wine, and lower alcohol drinks are $5. Got a very nice Sangria, fruity, could taste the wine without being knocked flat.

Waiter told me they had added a side Little Gem lettuce salad. Just what I needed as a first course after a weekend of rich food. Pretty basic, lettuce wedges, thin slices of radish and cucumber, with vinaigrette. But nothing wrong with a basic salad.

Decided on meat loaf as I have not had meat loaf in years! Came with smashed potatoes and root vegetables, both decent, not outstanding. Meat loaf was very good but frankly, although they called it meat loaf Wellington and therefore I knew it was bread wrapped, found the bread extraneous. I liked the taste but maybe by the end of the weekend of foodie-ism was a bit "over-starched". 

For dessert I might under other circumstances have had the brownie sundae (which did sound good) but alas, Corridor suffered by being the last of my four restaurants in a weekend. Tried the apple tart. The tart was good, so was the ice cream, so was the caramel sauce. But it was garnished with dice and thin slices of apple that were so sour they set my teeth on edge. I have eaten Granny Smith many times, they are tart but not sour like this. They tasted unripe. The apples in the tart were fine so maybe they just had an unripe apple that became my garnish.

I have to say this. I was one of the first two parties (OK, party of one) seated and everyone else in the dining room, including people who arrived well after me, got their food before I did. Possibly it was just that meat loaf takes longer to cook than everything else, possibly some minor kitchen error. I do like to give benefit of the doubt. But being a woman who often dines solo, it has happened too many times so I always wonder - was it just chance or was I considered a less important customer than couples/groups/men?
author: Carol S.

description: Oh my god food so good. Also a really nice space, with a downstairs and an upstairs eating area. Everything I have ordered here has been great - I have been three times and ordered something different every time, and I've never been disappointed. Especially for the price, the food is really top notch!
author: Serena D.

description: Great atmosphere and incredible food. The service was spot on. We were there for a business lunch thanks to the recommendation of our client and couldn't have been happier with the selection. The server suggested I try the salmon and it was perfect. The concept really works and I highly recommend.
author: Tim K.

description: The food was mediocre. My trout salad was over powered by the horseradish dressing. Husband's meat dish was just ok. Monkey bread app was excessively greasy. The atmosphere is a bit like a coffee shop rather than fine dining. The service was not great. Had to wait a long time to order 2nd round of drinks.
author: Susan E.

description: I love this place! Our neighborhood needed a casual, approachable place with great food and that's what Corridor provides. I work at home so I love that they start serving dinner at 3pm and their happy hour featuring $5 wine is superb. I've tried the flat bread, several of their pastas, and the burrata salad. Everything was fresh and delicious. It's fun to sit at the bar and watch the staff buzz around, making food, etc.
author: Mark S.

description: Delicious. From meatballs to pasta, every dish was satisfying. I loved the risotto and the ribeye, and the concept of small plates shared family style.
author: Kristen S.

description: Good food and A class service - I had the calamari misto and the corn risotto. Both dishes were flavorful - different takes on the classics. The misto came with aioli harissa and pickled vegetables which gave the fried sea food a whole different taste. The risotto was different as well - maybe best risotto I had, light and fluffy, came with mushrooms and corns with a truffle sauce - really good! The waiter was great, I have not took down his name but he deserves a public commendation  - not only he gave me the best recommendations but service was impeccable. Understand now why Corridor is one of the restaurants still standing on that block, there were a few more at some moment but they did not last...
author: VIORICA C.

description: So many good places to eat in SF, won't come back here. The place is noisy. I had a shrimp roll that was pretty terrible, but the fries were good. Calamari appetizer was tasty but the monkey bread was greasy. My friend had the roast chicken, which was good but way underseasoned. And the place is too pretentious to put salt on the table.
author: Lisa C.

description: Outstanding meal which was shared with friends! Happy hour wine before 6 which was so good. We started with spicy meatballs and monkey bread. Second course was calamari misty with sun hikes plus risotto with mushrooms, cheese and truffle oil. Yummy! Then meatloaf Wellington which was to die for! Dessert course was apple gallete and ice cream sundae. Perfect conclusion to a meal which was terrific!
author: Mary H.

description:
What you're getting for this price is amazing. Very affordable for this level and calibre of food. 
Wonderful, friendly & impeccable service.
Best French Onion Soup broth we've ever had.
The Falafel was light and crumbly, not dense at all. 
Calamari was excellent. Who would have thought of that combination of ingredients?! Everything worked perfectly. 
Meatballs had a rich, tomato sauce - not too acidic, well balanced, the peppers were delicious.
The Trout salad was beautifully made and dressed - but if you're not a fan of hard-boiled eggs, be forewarned! Eggs were crumbled all over the salad. However, the eggs are a perfect compliment to the dressing. 
The Little Gem salad was good, but a little more average than the other fare - but hey! For $6, it's great!
author: Mean J.

description: Located on Van Ness and Fell, I've been eyeing corridor via Yelp for a minute. But with a soar throat yesterday, decided it's time to finally their French onion soup. Rave Yelp reviews about monkey bread,then  their falafels looked interesting too. Everything was delicious!! We were busy killing the apps so didn't notice but bc the soup took a little longer to come out, they were kind enough to throw in their meatball app which was also great. Husband tried their Belgian beer- lots of beer draft options. Overall I'm in trouble bc I'm going to want everything we tried often, especially the monkey bread! Great service and awesome food!
author: Jesley J.

description: Great restaurant. After a supremely lackluster brunch, my expectations were very low for this place, holding nothing against it, as I'd never been. Just being seated by someone would have been a win. Thankfully, this restaurant delivered. Parking, since it's near the theater and the civic center, is unbelievably difficult, so don't even bother trying to park nearby. We ended up about 6 minutes away somehow, which was another win in itself. I had an Open Table reservation, so even though I was about 5-10 minutes late, the restaurant was able to seat us quickly (you check in on the first floor, and go upstairs. They have a high top table area/bar downstairs). We sat along the rail, so we could people watch from above. The space upstairs is extremely limited, and only one-two people handle all of the logistics. They really never stop moving. The server was nice and accomodating, and made sure we never had to wait too long for anything. Went with just a plain pilsner to start off (not many cocktails listed, I don't think they offer a full bar upstairs or something), which I have no complaints with. The monkey bread was raved about, so I made sure to get some. It's like a gourmet cheese bread, really. Very soft and easy to tear into, I liked it. The lasagna was spot on: great sauce, and even a tint of spice (probably the salsa verde, very unique). I liked they also gave you extra sauce to dump all over if you wanted more. I really liked the Radicchio too. My girlfriend's burger was good too, it was not as pink as I'd thought it'd be, but still tasty. Bathrooms are downstairs, so you do have to do a little limbo-ing to get past the servers, who are booking it up the stairs getting orders out to people. Nothing too crazy though. Even saw an ADA lift nearby if you have disabled guests. All in all, great bounceback dinner, and would be back to try other items.
author: Dan M.

description:
Wow, what great service and experience.   We were greeted with smiles and had such an enjoyable meal from the service (Thanks Matt!) to the dishes we selected.  We shared the pasta dish and the meatloaf and paired it with a nice merlot - both dishes were really fresh and flavorful and large portions.  This is a quick walk from the Orpheum if anyone is looking for a nice place to eat after seeing a performance.   We also tried your non alcoholic mohito and that was refreshing.

Matt and Corridor, thanks for making it an awesome evening out!!  We will be back to try your other dishes.
author: Jennifer E.

description: OMG, can we go back here right now, please?! Food was amazing, server was super friendly and attentive and funny, and we sat in the upstairs balcony, looking out at the street, watching folks walk their dogs and scurry by on their way to a Saturday evening out. Wine was delicious too, and well matched to the food. (I had both a white and a red, before and with dinner.) I guess if I had to pick at something, I'd observe that they don't serve espresso drinks. Maybe, just maybe, I'll live. Traded food remarks (and little bites) with the couple seated next to us, who also looked to be enjoying the whole scene, and the flavors. We skipped dessert, because we were planning to have our sweets elsewhere, but their appetizer bread pudding (savory, not sweet) more than makes up for any calories you might have missed after the meal. All the selections were amazing. Can't wait to return!
author: Mr J.

description: The service is phenomenal. We showed up 45 minutes late to our reservation due to traffic and finding parking (obviously, we aren't from the city!) and the hostess still welcomed us to take a seat at the bar while our tables got ready with a couple glasses of champagne. The food was great. My wife enjoyed the salmon, and I enjoyed the bolo.
author: Hamilton S.

description: 3 stars is generous. The ordering system was confusing. No one knew whether they were in the right line and it took too long. We didn't get a number so were surprised when they knew who to give our food to. It was so incredibly loud for lunch that it ruined the meal. Small menu. Small soup portion.
author: Tish M.

description: Really good. French onion soup fabulous.  Bar stools hard to get in and out for older short folk and wait staff very helpful.
author: G H.

description: In general I thought everything at corridor was solid but not awesome. Ambiance I don't love; feels pretty sterile. Service was very good and attentive, or at least I didn't notice any gaps. Beer list is pretty great actually; wine less so but fine. I thought the food was "fine".  Actually, pretty much every dish was "almost there", but they all landed on decent. I was debating whether this review should be 3 stars, but pretty much everything was above average. The bummer is that nothing was way above average (except the beer list, surprisingly!).
author: Amjad S.

description: Very happy to discover this new (relatively... 9 months) addition to the Civic Center dining options. We tried it after a matinee at the SF Symphony, and had a great experience sitting at the bar. Our sampling of the menu was limited, but both the duck confit & chicories salad and the spicy meatballs were great, and the ambiance was pleasant.  I particularly recommend the duck confit salad. The combination of asian pear, mint, and a creamy dressing partly made of a poached egg you mix in yourself, paired with the salty duck, was inspired.
author: Viviana R.

description: I had previously been there a few times for coffee but my coworker told me they have so much more, specifically goat cheese pretzels, mimosa parfait and breakfast burrito (made with tater tots), as well as great pastries, all of which were delicious.  I haven't tried their lunch yet, but plan to.  One star off for their happy hour, which is for drinks only, not food.
author: a f.

description: Such a cute little cozy place. It represents the new style of restaurants opening in San Francisco and I saw this restaurant in the Food section article in the sunday paper. Me and my boyfriend reserved a table and decided to take uber there because of the difficult parking. So when you reserved a table , you're suppose to check in at the register to receive a keychain (?) To give to the server upstairs. Okays so we thought we get a table, but naw we got seated on a counter table with other people sitting in. Didn't like that , so we told him that we wanted a table and he moved us when the table behind us moved. The second floor is so damn small!!! So congested and it gets super duper loud up there that you cannot hear your thoughts because the table next to us was very obxnious. The food wasn't that great, but decent with the vegetable pot pie. If I'm around the area I'll try something different .
author: Annie L.

description: They are super rude to our party and I don't think its worth even 1 star. Their manager was especially rude an refused service claiming that we were intoxicated (we were not).
author: Ian Y.

description: Solid 4 stars for sure. Enjoyed Trestle and Stones Throw so wanted to try out Corridor. The space is large, lots of space and seems really easy to just walk into on a weeknight (although we had made reservations). The falafel appetizer was so delicious I could have ordered a couple more. French onion soup was good - but glad we shared it (wasn't wonderful enough to have an entire bowl of or have as your meal). Also ordered the chicken parmesan (pretty good, but a little hard to eat) and the shrimp roll.
author: Emily K.

description: Amazing food. Monkey Bread my favorite. Gruyere french onion soup like explosion in my mouth. Amazing service & nice ambiance
author: Taryn M.

description: Been here twice, good experiences both times.  Friendly staff, nice contemporary environs, reasonable pricing.  Good beer menu, wine ok.  Enjoyed the pan roasted salmon twice, smoked trout salad was good as well.  Kind of a cross-over in terms of format, but as counter dwellers good place for us!
author: Glenn S.

description: Just had an incredible time at this wonderful gem. Too bad this concept is not offered in DC, I hope to try one of their sister restaurants before I leave. My understanding the Chef is Jason Halverson and he absolutely knows what he's doing. Me and my friend had a cocktail and some food. We shared some fries, ordered the brocollini for each of ourselves, and she had the French onion soup. The french onion soup was prepared a little different than what I'm used to. This presentation included tender beef, and tomatoes with the standard ingredients that make up French onion soup.
author: Jarrett C.

description: I'm sad to give this place a three star review but it really deserves it. The counter ordering makes it feel like a deli and yet you pay restaurant prices. They serve you your food but it didn't feel like restaurant service. It feel like deli service, like someone serving you your sandwich. It surprises me that this is a sister restaurant to Stones Throw. The food did not match the quality, nor did the service or the ambiance. Save your money and go to Stones Throw.
author: Stacy M.

description: Eh. The burgers were reaaally mediocre. $10 beers and $12/glass of wine. $105 for dinner for two. Cool vibe but I doubt we'll be back
author: Marcel C.

description: Great food. Monkey bread and meatballs are so good. My colleagues said Wellington is great. I love my duck confit salad. The portion is huge :)
author: Vy T.

description: We had a similar experience to Cody's.   The concept just didn't seem to be going smoothly.
author: F C.

description: Came here for a quick happy hour before hopping on bart foe the Warriors game and was really pleased overall. Their happy hour menu is a GREAT deal, with all beer, wine, and cocktails offered for $5. I will say that I wish the cocktails weren't "low proof" and had a little more kick to them, but they definitely taste great even if you don't get much of a buzz off them. We were seated right at the bar so we were also able to look right into the open kitchen where they were plating the food, which looked really good. Would love to come back for dinner one day, but highly recommend stopping by for their amazing happy hour!
author: Jaymie S.

description: The food is good but it's nearly impossible to reach anyone on the telephone to place an order for takeout. I just called over 20 minutes and no one picked up.
author: Kevin K.

description: First time and I like everything about this place from the food to the business model (not wasting money on menus, ordering up front, seating yourself) who doesn't love efficiency?! My burger was cooked to perfection, although I'm not a fan of pickled veggies on a burger, it was still tasty. Excellent service by the hostess, waitress, and cooks. No complaints.
author: Sheena J.

description:
Read about this place in the Sunday Chronicle and wanted to give it a try. We were going to the theater and this was a perfect location. I was unable to get a reservation for the time I wanted on Open Table so I called the restaurant. The hostess told me she would call if a table opened up ....she called that afternoon. Great service already! 
We were a group of 4. We started with the monkey bread , which was delicious! We had an assortment of items, all very good! French onion soup was great!  Everyone at the table was pleased with their choice. Service is good, very friendly staff. We were upstairs, which was still a bit noisy, but not bad. 
I would definitely go back, especially if heading to the theater. Very reasonable prices, portions are big. They have a nice happy hour too, which helps with the bar bill! Wish we could have tried dessert, but we were all stuffed! 
Great place all around!
author: Lisa B.

description: This place is amazing. Delicious food, great ambiance and the Staff is so amazingly attentive and friendly. Thai is so nice and personable. I suggest for everyone to go and check them out.
author: Khalilah C.

description: We were there to celebrate our wedding with a few of our friends .it was the perfect  choice ,everyone had a great time the service are great the food was yummy and best of all I was with my husband and we had a great and wonderful reception,,
author: Rommel G.

description: Slightly different style of ordering food, first you order at the counter, then you grab a seat, after you eat, you pay. If done otherwise they aren't shy to let you know you are wrong. I found this a little awkward after trying to look at the menu at a table quickly to be told to get back to the counter. The food is good however and that's why I'll give them the benefit of doubt.
author: Winston S.

description: Good service, nice location. Lasagne and monkey bread were ok, below my expectations. It is not worth the hype.
author: Javier S.

description: The vegetable pot pie is everything I could ask for - light as a cloud. The skin is uber crispy and the parmesan sauce inside is delicious. Don't miss out on the beautiful desserts too. I had a cherry tart that was accented with a fresh mint sauce. There was a nilla wafer one that was super tempting too.
author: Joyce L.

description: Expected more based on reviews. Chicken avocado salad tasted off/awful. Avocado had brown spots and tasted like vinegar (clearly bad), chicken was dry and flavorless (unless you count the slightly old taste), greens were soggy and overdressed (in gross greasy dressing), bacon was dry and had a weird taste, ... Overall, there was a bitter taste, and the combination of bad & old ingredients didn't taste good. Left with a stomach ache, looking for anything to eat that would change the bad taste in my mouth. Maybe Monday is an off day for them; regardless, I don't think I will go back to try something else given the lingering bitter taste in my mouth and stomach ache.
author: Ruth C.

description: Such a great experience! The food was exceptional and the atmosphere was welcoming. I have no problem paying a high price for quality food and a great dining experience, but I was overwhelmingly satisfied at the combination of high end fare with reasonable prices. You'll recognize some of the items from the menu of their well known Stones Throw restaurant. My husband and I shared the meatballs, mozz and buratta salad, burger and pot pie. Every item was cooked and seasoned to perfection. It's a great place for lunch or dinner! We were able to walk right in on a Sat pm and sit at the bar, but I don't suspect that will be the case for much longer. Highly recommend checking it out! We will definitely be back!!
author: Dee D.

description: OK, but nothing to write home about. The decor was a bit boring and the food was pretty good, but nothing really stood out. The meatloaf was delicious though.
author: Lucks N.

description: We went for dinner and got a reservation, so we sat upstairs. The ambiance is airy and modern and not pretentious - although the service was equivalent to a higher-end place! The food was just really, really good - we had the veggie pot pie and the meatloaf and everything was fresh and well-crafted. We've gotten take-out a few times so have basically eaten everything on the menu. Excellent consistency from one time to the next (even taken out!), comfort food at its finest. Get the monkey bread if you can spare yourself a minor indulgence. We had an easy time finding street parking even though it was Sat night.
author: Amy H.

description:
Favorite new local joint, I'm on my 10th visit?

People are GREAT!  really delightful.

Almost everything has been solid, interesting, etc.  Favorite: monkey bread and French onion soup (together).

Not excited: salads, lasagne.
author: adam s.

description: Food is amazing and the service was even better. Was my first time going here after moving to the city and it was a very comfy ambiance. I would recommend this place.
author: Jonathan L.

description: Dinner at Corridor was a very disappointing experience.  Most disappointing was the food, none of which I would order again. The sunchokes were nearly raw and were covered with raw flour, the vinaigrette on the salmon tasted like it was bottled, and the little gem salad with dijon vinaigrette tasted only like horseradish.  It is difficult to believe that Michael Bauer gave Corridor any stars in his Chronicle review. Our service was almost nonexistent until we spoke with the manager.  She was responsive and they subsequently became much more engaged and for that I am appreciative.  It comes down to the food for me and it was simply horrible.
author: Leslie C.

description: Casual Setting. The food was amazing, the service tops the food. Someone is right new to you before your water glass is empty. Ambiance is relaxed new American traditional food and matching decor.
author: Tina W.

description:
Burger was unstoppable!  So good.

Doesn't photograph super well, but don't be alerted.

Must taste... I added the aoli from my fries to it as well.
author: Trevor S.

description: Excellent new dinner spot with some of our favorite dishes from Trestle.   We loved the mock-tails too.  Great prices, beautiful space, attentive staff.  Can't wait to come back and save room for dessert!
author: Kim K.

description: Waited an hour for any of our appetizers/food as we watched all the remaining customers trickle out. Turns out our order "never reached the printer," but we weren't given that explanation until I was already embarrassed in front of my bosses. I had told them how highly recommended our chosen restaurant was. Hardly apologetic, and nothing was comped - not even an appetizer. I understand things happen and tend to give folks the benefit of the doubt, but I left feeling very awkward and disappointed.
author: Taylor M.

description: Quality reminds me of Applebees!   We had such a meh meal tonight.   The monkey bread was excellent, but after that, the meal went downhill.   The trout salad was smothered in egg, potato, green beans and other cheap ingredients -- where was the smoked trout?   I counted six micro bites.  The risotto was cooked days ago and reheated.   The savory bread pudding wasn't really bread pudding -- rather a brioche style roll with a cream sauce (that was NOT raclette).   The quality does not match the pricing.  Next time, just go to Applebees!   We will not ever be back again and predict this restaurant will close within the year.
author: Jim S.

description: So disappointing.  It is the service, or lack thereof, that has made the experience so distasteful. The parent company's website says "....every member of the team strives to create a memorable experience for all of our guests" -- I guess they succeeded, as I do remember it, however, the memory is an unpleasant one.
author: Rosy P.

description: Tasty, hearty food at a reasonable price. One of my new faves!
author: Aiko S.

description:
Corridor does a great job of introducing a new style of restaurant service, in the context of excellent food.  Although it was a bit different when we first arrived, I really liked the informal approach of ordering at the counter, followed by more traditional, attentive service.

Foodwise, the main standout for me was the french onion soup.  It was incredibly rich, and hearty, with none of the oiliness of some french onion soups; perfect for a foggy day in SF.  And although Corridor only has low-proof cocktails, the Pimm's Cup was exceptional (especially when backed with an excellent selection of beers).

Corridor is certainly worth checking out....and returning to often!
author: Leland B.

description: Little gem! Good food, great service... etc.
author: Stuart C.

description: Everything was amazing from beginning to end. Calamari, chicory salad and the salmon were the highlights of the evening. Service was very friendly and attentive.
author: Jane U.

description: Went to a retirement party and loved the food, so returned to order take out lunch.  When we returned to the office the order was missing items.. Called the restaurant and Alissa told me to come back when were ready and they would replace it.  That was early December.  I called yesterday to take Alissa up on her offer and she was off.  Her colleague was aware of the situation and told me to come get my lunch.  I ordered additional items and when I went to pay, they said lunch was on them.  My order was perfect and so was the customer service.  Was a great staff at this restaurant.
author: April W.

description: I really wanted to like Corridor as it's from the same family as Trestle and Stones Throw but unfortunately, it doesn't measure up.  I had the corn chowder, monkey bread, squid ink pasta and rib eye.  The corn chowder and monkey bread were the best out of the bunch.  I was extreme disappointed in the squid ink pasta, definitely not as good as Stones Throw.  Hopefully it's just growing pains.
author: M C.

description: I'll try anything once... Burger was just ok, corn chowder was bland... No second chances for this fast food concept.
author: Ezra B.

description: We had a celebratory lunch for 12 people after my daughter's wedding. The food was delicious and the service exceptional!
author: Judy K.

description: What a delightful restaurant. This brand new eatery is a welcome addition to the Civic Center area of San Francisco. Two decades (and before) ago, no one would do anything but scurry through this area--very seedy. Downright scary. However, in the last couple of years, this area "woke" up, the Vitamin D came in to feed creative people and lo, The Corridor Restaurant appeared.  What an attentive staff!  What professional and friendly managers! What terrific food!  Light dishes and full meals are available in several combinations. Try the "Little Gem" salad--it belongs on a magazine cover--just a picture of crisp romaine slices with perfect little radish dials, and just a dribble of savory dressing. Try the pesto-covered roasted carrots! DO NOT miss the Falafel Croquettes--you will swoon, just swoon. I am afraid every time I go in that I will lose control and just order two dozen plates of those!!! When you arrive, march purposefully to your left and place your order. Don't dither as there are a dozen people behind you hungrier than you! You are given a little glowing coaster that has a GPS finder which will direct the server as to where you are in the restaurant--either next to the HUGE curved picture window (what that must have cost!) or hiding upstairs in a little romantic corner so you can sip your favorite beverage and kiss your sweetie. The spicy meatballs are a wonderful addition to the meal. NO hard distilled liquor is served, but innovative beers and unusual wines are always available. They cleverly sunk the menu into the tables themselves so you can pull out the list again to order MORE once you've stuffed yourself with those falafels!  (To be fair: I wrote a similar positive review on Trip Advisor about this wonderful new place!)
author: Elle W.

description: Food was good, seats were cold and hard.  All seating was at high cocktail tables.  Welcome was not very warm or welcoming, but wait staff and chef were great.
author: Eileen M.

description: Wonderful experience on all counts, food, service, ambiance, etc. My friends and I tried various mains and sides and they were all really scrumptious. The tomato salad stands out as does the calamari. Be sure to check this newcomer out. I think you'll like it a lot. I'll be back for more!
author: Janice H.

description: Dropped by on my way to an appointment. Glad I was early cuz I stayed until my appointment! Very inviting, clean place. I tried their cauliflower salad: yummy!! And then I tried their chocolate chip cookie with coffee and I was set! I will definitely return if I'm back in the neighborhood.
author: Locelia P.

description: Tried it for the first time after the theater show on Market Street. Although a bit rushed, ordering at the counter was OK. The comfort food was excellent. Everything was as described in the food critic's column in the Chronicle. Service staff was a bit hasty on removing things from the table, which made us feel a bit rushed. I would definitely go back for the food and sit upstairs next time.
author: Mary S.

description: Incredible food, just the small plates. The most beautiful waitress. I'll go anytime. Haven't even tried the etrees!
author: Peter K.

description: Absolutely wonderful!  Great atmosphere. We shared a bunch of plates and they were all delicious! The meatballs blew my mind. I could see this being a great place to go to before the theatre. Coming back!
author: Morgan P.

description: I went there the other night and I have to say the food was great! I got the chicken parm sandwich and everything about it was perfect. But I have to mention the young female bartender was not that great. First she didn't know what a pilsner was, I had to explain it to her and then point to it on the menu before she was like "ohhh". Second multiple people including myself asked her for recommendations and she had no idea what to recommended. I was not impressed with the bar service but everyone else was great!
author: Kat S.

description: At first glance I was hesitant over ordering before sitting down, but was impressed by the monkey bread and housemade soda. My wife and I shared a burger and Cobb Salad, both of which are among the best food we have experienced in San Francisco. Eating here was not only wonderful, but the service was supurb and a wonderful meal prior to the symphony 1 block away.
author: Scott C.
